java_jndi_injection_exploitation_attempt.title: Potential JNDI Injection Exploitation In JVM Based Application
java_jndi_injection_exploitation_attempt.status: Detects potential JNDI Injection exploitation. Often coupled with Log4Shell exploitation.
java_jndi_injection_exploitation_attempt.description: Detects potential JNDI Injection exploitation. Often coupled with Log4Shell exploitation.
java_jndi_injection_exploitation_attempt.author: Moti Harmats

logsource.definition: Requirements: application error logs must be collected (with LOG_LEVEL=ERROR and above)

java_local_file_read.yml.title: Potential Local File Read Vulnerability In JVM Based Application
java_local_file_read.yml.status:
Detects potential local file read vulnerability in JVM based apps.
If the exceptions are caused due to user input and contain path traversal payloads then it's a red flag.
java_local_file_read.yml.description:
Detects potential local file read vulnerability in JVM based apps.
If the exceptions are caused due to user input and contain path traversal payloads then it's a red flag.
java_local_file_read.yml.author: Moti Harmats

logsource.definition: Requirements: application error logs must be collected (with LOG_LEVEL=ERROR and above)

java_ognl_injection_exploitation_attempt.title: Potential OGNL Injection Exploitation In JVM Based Application
java_ognl_injection_exploitation_attempt.status:
Detects potential OGNL Injection exploitation, which may lead to RCE.
OGNL is an expression language that is supported in many JVM based systems.
OGNL Injection is the reason for some high profile RCE's such as Apache Struts (CVE-2017-5638) and Confluence (CVE-2022-26134)
java_ognl_injection_exploitation_attempt.description:
Detects potential OGNL Injection exploitation, which may lead to RCE.
OGNL is an expression language that is supported in many JVM based systems.
OGNL Injection is the reason for some high profile RCE's such as Apache Struts (CVE-2017-5638) and Confluence (CVE-2022-26134)
java_ognl_injection_exploitation_attempt.author: Moti Harmats

logsource.definition: Requirements: application error logs must be collected (with LOG_LEVEL=ERROR and above)

java_xxe_exploitation_attempt.yml.title: Potential XXE Exploitation Attempt In JVM Based Application
java_xxe_exploitation_attempt.yml.status: Detects XML parsing issues, if the application expects to work with XML make sure that the parser is initialized safely.
java_xxe_exploitation_attempt.yml.description: Detects XML parsing issues, if the application expects to work with XML make sure that the parser is initialized safely.
java_xxe_exploitation_attempt.yml.author: Moti Harmats

logsource.definition: Requirements: application error logs must be collected (with LOG_LEVEL=ERROR and above)

falsepositives: If the application expects to work with XML there may be parsing issues that don't necessarily mean XXE.

nodejs_rce_exploitation_attempt.yml.description: Detects process execution related errors in NodeJS. If the exceptions are caused due to user input then they may suggest an RCE vulnerability.

db_anomalous_query.yml.title: Suspicious SQL Query

aws_attached_malicious_lambda_layer.yml.title: AWS Attached Malicious Lambda Layer
aws_attached_malicious_lambda_layer.yml.status:
Detects when an user attached a Lambda layer to an existing function to override a library that is in use by the function, where their malicious code could utilize the function's IAM role for AWS API calls.
This would give an adversary access to the privileges associated with the Lambda service role that is attached to that function.
aws_attached_malicious_lambda_layer.yml.description:
Detects when an user attached a Lambda layer to an existing function to override a library that is in use by the function, where their malicious code could utilize the function's IAM role for AWS API calls.
This would give an adversary access to the privileges associated with the Lambda service role that is attached to that function.
aws_attached_malicious_lambda_layer.yml.author: Austin Songer
falsepositives: Lambda Layer being attached may be performed by a system administrator. Verify whether the user identity, user agent, and/or hostname should be making changes in your environment.
Lambda Layer being attached from unfamiliar users should be investigated. If known behavior is causing false positives, it can be exempted from the rule.

aws_delete_identity.yml.title: SES Identity Has Been Deleted

aws_ec2_disable_encryption.yml.title: AWS EC2 Disable EBS Encryption
aws_ec2_disable_encryption.yml.status:
Identifies disabling of default Amazon Elastic Block Store (EBS) encryption in the current region.
Disabling default encryption does not change the encryption status of your existing volumes.
aws_ec2_disable_encryption.yml.description:
Identifies disabling of default Amazon Elastic Block Store (EBS) encryption in the current region.
Disabling default encryption does not change the encryption status of your existing volumes.
aws_ec2_disable_encryption.yml.author: Sittikorn S
falsepositives: DEV, UAT, SAT environment. You should apply this rule with PROD account only.

aws_ec2_startup_script_change.yml.title: AWS EC2 Startup Shell Script Change
aws_ec2_startup_script_change.yml.status: Detects changes to the EC2 instance startup script. The shell script will be executed as root/SYSTEM every time the specific instances are booted up.
aws_ec2_startup_script_change.yml.description: Detects changes to the EC2 instance startup script. The shell script will be executed as root/SYSTEM every time the specific instances are booted up.
aws_ec2_startup_script_change.yml.author: faloker
falsepositives: Valid changes to the startup script

aws_ec2_vm_export_failure.yml.title: AWS EC2 VM Export Failure
aws_ec2_vm_export_failure.yml.status: An attempt to export an AWS EC2 instance has been detected. A VM Export might indicate an attempt to extract information from an instance.
aws_ec2_vm_export_failure.yml.description: An attempt to export an AWS EC2 instance has been detected. A VM Export might indicate an attempt to extract information from an instance.
aws_ec2_vm_export_failure.yml.author: Diogo Braz

aws_ecs_task_definition_cred_endpoint_qu.title: AWS ECS Task Definition That Queries The Credential Endpoint
aws_ecs_task_definition_cred_endpoint_qu.status:
Detects when an Elastic Container Service (ECS) Task Definition includes a command to query the credential endpoint.
This can indicate a potential adversary adding a backdoor to establish persistence or escalate privileges.
aws_ecs_task_definition_cred_endpoint_qu.description:
Detects when an Elastic Container Service (ECS) Task Definition includes a command to query the credential endpoint.
This can indicate a potential adversary adding a backdoor to establish persistence or escalate privileges.
aws_ecs_task_definition_cred_endpoint_qu.author: Darin Smith
falsepositives: Task Definition being modified to request credentials from the Task Metadata Service for valid reasons

aws_efs_fileshare_modified_or_deleted.ym.title: AWS EFS Fileshare Modified or Deleted
aws_efs_fileshare_modified_or_deleted.ym.status:
Detects when a EFS Fileshare is modified or deleted.
You can't delete a file system that is in use.
If the file system has any mount targets, the adversary must first delete them, so deletion of a mount will occur before deletion of a fileshare.
aws_efs_fileshare_modified_or_deleted.ym.description:
Detects when a EFS Fileshare is modified or deleted.
You can't delete a file system that is in use.
If the file system has any mount targets, the adversary must first delete them, so deletion of a mount will occur before deletion of a fileshare.
aws_efs_fileshare_modified_or_deleted.ym.author: Austin Songer @austinsonger

aws_efs_fileshare_mount_modified_or_dele.title: AWS EFS Fileshare Mount Modified or Deleted
aws_efs_fileshare_mount_modified_or_dele.status: Detects when a EFS Fileshare Mount is modified or deleted. An adversary breaking any file system using the mount target that is being deleted, which might disrupt instances or applications using those mounts.
aws_efs_fileshare_mount_modified_or_dele.description: Detects when a EFS Fileshare Mount is modified or deleted. An adversary breaking any file system using the mount target that is being deleted, which might disrupt instances or applications using those mounts.
aws_efs_fileshare_mount_modified_or_dele.author: Austin Songer @austinsonger

aws_eks_cluster_created_or_deleted.yml.title: AWS EKS Cluster Created or Deleted
aws_eks_cluster_created_or_deleted.yml.status: Identifies when an EKS cluster is created or deleted.
aws_eks_cluster_created_or_deleted.yml.description: Identifies when an EKS cluster is created or deleted.
aws_eks_cluster_created_or_deleted.yml.author: Austin Songer
falsepositives: EKS Cluster being created or deleted may be performed by a system administrator.
Verify whether the user identity, user agent, and/or hostname should be making changes in your environment.
EKS Cluster created or deleted from unfamiliar users should be investigated. If known behavior is causing false positives, it can be exempted from the rule.

aws_iam_backdoor_users_keys.yml.title: AWS IAM Backdoor Users Keys
aws_iam_backdoor_users_keys.yml.status:
Detects AWS API key creation for a user by another user.
Backdoored users can be used to obtain persistence in the AWS environment.
Also with this alert, you can detect a flow of AWS keys in your org.
aws_iam_backdoor_users_keys.yml.description:

aws_iam_backdoor_users_keys.yml.author: faloker
falsepositives: Adding user keys to their own accounts (the filter cannot cover all possible variants of user naming)
AWS API keys legitimate exchange workflows

aws_update_login_profile.yml.title: AWS User Login Profile Was Modified
aws_update_login_profile.yml.status:
An attacker with the iam:UpdateLoginProfile permission on other users can change the password used to login to the AWS console on any user that already has a login profile setup.
With this alert, it is used to detect anyone is changing password on behalf of other users.

azure_aadhybridhealth_adfs_new_server.ym.title: Azure Active Directory Hybrid Health AD FS New Server
azure_aadhybridhealth_adfs_new_server.ym.status:
This detection uses azureactivity logs (Administrative category) to identify the creation or update of a server instance in an Azure AD Hybrid health AD FS service.
A threat actor can create a new AD Health ADFS service and create a fake server instance to spoof AD FS signing logs. There is no need to compromise an on-prem AD FS server.
This can be done programmatically via HTTP requests to Azure.
azure_aadhybridhealth_adfs_new_server.ym.description:
This detection uses azureactivity logs (Administrative category) to identify the creation or update of a server instance in an Azure AD Hybrid health AD FS service.
A threat actor can create a new AD Health ADFS service and create a fake server instance to spoof AD FS signing logs. There is no need to compromise an on-prem AD FS server.
This can be done programmatically via HTTP requests to Azure.
azure_aadhybridhealth_adfs_new_server.ym.author: Roberto Rodriguez (Cyb3rWard0g), OTR (Open Threat Research), MSTIC
falsepositives: Legitimate AD FS servers added to an AAD Health AD FS service instance

azure_aadhybridhealth_adfs_service_delet.title: Azure Active Directory Hybrid Health AD FS Service Delete
azure_aadhybridhealth_adfs_service_delet.status:
This detection uses azureactivity logs (Administrative category) to identify the deletion of an Azure AD Hybrid health AD FS service instance in a tenant.
A threat actor can create a new AD Health ADFS service and create a fake server to spoof AD FS signing logs.
The health AD FS service can then be deleted after it is not longer needed via HTTP requests to Azure.
azure_aadhybridhealth_adfs_service_delet.description:
This detection uses azureactivity logs (Administrative category) to identify the deletion of an Azure AD Hybrid health AD FS service instance in a tenant.
A threat actor can create a new AD Health ADFS service and create a fake server to spoof AD FS signing logs.
The health AD FS service can then be deleted after it is not longer needed via HTTP requests to Azure.
azure_aadhybridhealth_adfs_service_delet.author: Roberto Rodriguez (Cyb3rWard0g), OTR (Open Threat Research), MSTIC
falsepositives: Legitimate AAD Health AD FS service instances being deleted in a tenant

azure_kubernetes_admission_controller.ym.title: Azure Kubernetes Admission Controller
azure_kubernetes_admission_controller.ym.status:
Identifies when an admission controller is executed in Azure Kubernetes.
A Kubernetes Admission controller intercepts, and possibly modifies, requests to the Kubernetes API server.
The behavior of this admission controller is determined by an admission webhook (MutatingAdmissionWebhook or ValidatingAdmissionWebhook) that the user deploys in the cluster.
An adversary can use such webhooks as the MutatingAdmissionWebhook for obtaining persistence in the cluster.
For example, attackers can intercept and modify the pod creation operations in the cluster and add their malicious container to every created pod.
An adversary can use the webhook ValidatingAdmissionWebhook, which could be used to obtain access credentials.
An adversary could use the webhook to intercept the requests to the API server, record secrets, and other sensitive information.

azure_kubernetes_admission_controller.ym.author: Austin Songer @austinsonger

azure_kubernetes_cronjob.yml.title: Azure Kubernetes CronJob
azure_kubernetes_cronjob.yml.status:
Identifies when a Azure Kubernetes CronJob runs in Azure Cloud. Kubernetes Job is a controller that creates one or more pods and ensures that a specified number of them successfully terminate.
Kubernetes Job can be used to run containers that perform finite tasks for batch jobs. Kubernetes CronJob is used to schedule Jobs.
An Adversary may use Kubernetes CronJob for scheduling execution of malicious code that would run as a container in the cluster.

azure_app_device_code_authentication.yml.title: Application Using Device Code Authentication Flow
azure_app_device_code_authentication.yml.status:
Device code flow is an OAuth 2.0 protocol flow specifically for input constrained devices and is not used in all environments.
If this type of flow is seen in the environment and not being used in an input constrained device scenario, further investigation is warranted.
This can be a misconfigured application or potentially something malicious.
azure_app_device_code_authentication.yml.description:
Device code flow is an OAuth 2.0 protocol flow specifically for input constrained devices and is not used in all environments.
If this type of flow is seen in the environment and not being used in an input constrained device scenario, further investigation is warranted.
This can be a misconfigured application or potentially something malicious.
azure_app_device_code_authentication.yml.author: Mark Morowczynski '@markmorow', Bailey Bercik '@baileybercik'
falsepositives: Applications that are input constrained will need to use device code flow and are valid authentications.

azure_app_ropc_authentication.yml.title: Applications That Are Using ROPC Authentication Flow
azure_app_ropc_authentication.yml.status:
Resource owner password credentials (ROPC) should be avoided if at all possible as this requires the user to expose their current password credentials to the application directly.
The application then uses those credentials to authenticate the user against the identity provider.
azure_app_ropc_authentication.yml.description:
Resource owner password credentials (ROPC) should be avoided if at all possible as this requires the user to expose their current password credentials to the application directly.
The application then uses those credentials to authenticate the user against the identity provider.
azure_app_ropc_authentication.yml.author: Mark Morowczynski '@markmorow', Bailey Bercik '@baileybercik'
falsepositives: Applications that are being used as part of automated testing or a legacy application that cannot use any other modern authentication flow

gcp_kubernetes_admission_controller.yml.title: Google Cloud Kubernetes Admission Controller
gcp_kubernetes_admission_controller.yml.status:
Identifies when an admission controller is executed in GCP Kubernetes.
A Kubernetes Admission controller intercepts, and possibly modifies, requests to the Kubernetes API server.
The behavior of this admission controller is determined by an admission webhook (MutatingAdmissionWebhook or ValidatingAdmissionWebhook) that the user deploys in the cluster.
An adversary can use such webhooks as the MutatingAdmissionWebhook for obtaining persistence in the cluster.
For example, attackers can intercept and modify the pod creation operations in the cluster and add their malicious container to every created pod. An adversary can use the webhook ValidatingAdmissionWebhook, which could be used to obtain access credentials.
An adversary could use the webhook to intercept the requests to the API server, record secrets, and other sensitive information.
gcp_kubernetes_admission_controller.yml.description:
Identifies when an admission controller is executed in GCP Kubernetes.
A Kubernetes Admission controller intercepts, and possibly modifies, requests to the Kubernetes API server.
The behavior of this admission controller is determined by an admission webhook (MutatingAdmissionWebhook or ValidatingAdmissionWebhook) that the user deploys in the cluster.
An adversary can use such webhooks as the MutatingAdmissionWebhook for obtaining persistence in the cluster.
For example, attackers can intercept and modify the pod creation operations in the cluster and add their malicious container to every created pod. An adversary can use the webhook ValidatingAdmissionWebhook, which could be used to obtain access credentials.
An adversary could use the webhook to intercept the requests to the API server, record secrets, and other sensitive information.
gcp_kubernetes_admission_controller.yml.author: Austin Songer @austinsonger
falsepositives: Google Cloud Kubernetes Admission Controller may be done by a system administrator.
If known behavior is causing false positives, it can be exempted from the rule.

gcp_kubernetes_cronjob.yml.title: Google Cloud Kubernetes CronJob
gcp_kubernetes_cronjob.yml.status:
Identifies when a Google Cloud Kubernetes CronJob runs in Azure Cloud. Kubernetes Job is a controller that creates one or more pods and ensures that a specified number of them successfully terminate.
Kubernetes Job can be used to run containers that perform finite tasks for batch jobs. Kubernetes CronJob is used to schedule Jobs.
An Adversary may use Kubernetes CronJob for scheduling execution of malicious code that would run as a container in the cluster.
gcp_kubernetes_cronjob.yml.description:
Identifies when a Google Cloud Kubernetes CronJob runs in Azure Cloud. Kubernetes Job is a controller that creates one or more pods and ensures that a specified number of them successfully terminate.
Kubernetes Job can be used to run containers that perform finite tasks for batch jobs. Kubernetes CronJob is used to schedule Jobs.
An Adversary may use Kubernetes CronJob for scheduling execution of malicious code that would run as a container in the cluster.
gcp_kubernetes_cronjob.yml.author: Austin Songer @austinsonger
falsepositives: Google Cloud Kubernetes CronJob/Job may be done by a system administrator.
If known behavior is causing false positives, it can be exempted from the rule.

github_self_hosted_runner_changes_detect.title: Github Self Hosted Runner Changes Detected
github_self_hosted_runner_changes_detect.status:
A self-hosted runner is a system that you deploy and manage to execute jobs from GitHub Actions on GitHub.com.
This rule detects changes to self-hosted runners configurations in the environment. The self-hosted runner configuration changes once detected,
it should be validated from GitHub UI because the log entry may not provide full context.
github_self_hosted_runner_changes_detect.description:
A self-hosted runner is a system that you deploy and manage to execute jobs from GitHub Actions on GitHub.com.
This rule detects changes to self-hosted runners configurations in the environment. The self-hosted runner configuration changes once detected,
it should be validated from GitHub UI because the log entry may not provide full context.
github_self_hosted_runner_changes_detect.author: Muhammad Faisal

logsource.definition: Requirements: The audit log streaming feature must be enabled to be able to receive such logs. You can enable following the documentation here: https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/monitoring-activity-in-your-enterprise/reviewing-audit-logs-for-your-enterprise/streaming-the-audit-log-for-your-enterprise#setting-up-audit-log-streaming

falsepositives: Allowed self-hosted runners changes in the environment.
A self-hosted runner is automatically removed from GitHub if it has not connected to GitHub Actions for more than 14 days.
An ephemeral self-hosted runner is automatically removed from GitHub if it has not connected to GitHub Actions for more than 1 day.

microsoft365_from_susp_ip_addresses.yml.status:
Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported users were active from an IP address identified as risky by Microsoft Threat Intelligence.
These IP addresses are involved in malicious activities, such as Botnet C&C, and may indicate compromised account.

microsoft365_activity_by_terminated_user.title: Activity Performed by Terminated User
microsoft365_activity_by_terminated_user.status:
Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported for users whose account were terminated in Azure AD, but still perform activities in other platforms such as AWS or Salesforce.
This is especially relevant for users who use another account to manage resources, since these accounts are often not terminated when a user leaves the company.

microsoft365_pst_export_alert.yml.title: PST Export Alert Using eDiscovery Alert
microsoft365_pst_export_alert.yml.status: Alert on when a user has performed an eDiscovery search or exported a PST file from the search. This PST file usually has sensitive information including email body content
microsoft365_pst_export_alert.yml.description: Alert on when a user has performed an eDiscovery search or exported a PST file from the search. This PST file usually has sensitive information including email body content
microsoft365_pst_export_alert.yml.author: Sorina Ionescu

logsource.definition: Requires the 'eDiscovery search or exported' alert to be enabled

falsepositives: PST export can be done for legitimate purposes but due to the sensitive nature of its content it must be monitored.

microsoft365_pst_export_alert_using_new_.title: PST Export Alert Using New-ComplianceSearchAction
microsoft365_pst_export_alert_using_new_.status: Alert when a user has performed an export to a search using 'New-ComplianceSearchAction' with the '-Export' flag. This detection will detect PST export even if the 'eDiscovery search or exported' alert is disabled in the O365.This rule will apply to ExchangePowerShell usage and from the cloud.
microsoft365_pst_export_alert_using_new_.description: Alert when a user has performed an export to a search using 'New-ComplianceSearchAction' with the '-Export' flag. This detection will detect PST export even if the 'eDiscovery search or exported' alert is disabled in the O365.This rule will apply to ExchangePowerShell usage and from the cloud.
microsoft365_pst_export_alert_using_new_.author: Nikita Khalimonenkov

This rule detect using dd and truncate to add a junk data to file.

lnx_auditd_bpfdoor_port_redirect.yml.title: Bpfdoor TCP Ports Redirect
lnx_auditd_bpfdoor_port_redirect.yml.status:
All TCP traffic on particular port from attacker is routed to different port. ex. '/sbin/iptables -t nat -D PREROUTING -p tcp -s 192.168.1.1 --dport 22 -j REDIRECT --to-ports 42392'
The traffic looks like encrypted SSH communications going to TCP port 22, but in reality is being directed to the shell port once it hits the iptables rule for the attacker host only.
lnx_auditd_bpfdoor_port_redirect.yml.description:
All TCP traffic on particular port from attacker is routed to different port. ex. '/sbin/iptables -t nat -D PREROUTING -p tcp -s 192.168.1.1 --dport 22 -j REDIRECT --to-ports 42392'
The traffic looks like encrypted SSH communications going to TCP port 22, but in reality is being directed to the shell port once it hits the iptables rule for the attacker host only.
lnx_auditd_bpfdoor_port_redirect.yml.author: Rafal Piasecki

lnx_auditd_data_exfil_wget.yml.status:
Detects attempts to post the file with the usage of wget utility.
The adversary can bypass the permission restriction with the misconfigured sudo permission for wget utility which could allow them to read files like /etc/shadow.

lnx_auditd_load_module_insmod.yml.title: Loading of Kernel Module via Insmod
lnx_auditd_load_module_insmod.yml.status:
Detects loading of kernel modules with insmod command.
Loadable Kernel Modules (LKMs) are pieces of code that can be loaded and unloaded into the kernel upon demand.
Adversaries may use LKMs to obtain persistence within the system or elevate the privileges.

lnx_auditd_masquerading_crond.yml.status:
Masquerading occurs when the name or location of an executable, legitimate or malicious, is manipulated or abused for the sake of evading defenses and observation.
Several different variations of this technique have been observed.

Detection rules that match only on the disabling of firewalls will miss this.

lnx_auditd_network_sniffing.yml.title: Network Sniffing - Linux
lnx_auditd_network_sniffing.yml.status:
Network sniffing refers to using the network interface on a system to monitor or capture information sent over a wired or wireless connection.
An adversary may place a network interface into promiscuous mode to passively access data in transit over the network, or use span ports to capture a larger amount of data.
lnx_auditd_network_sniffing.yml.description:
Network sniffing refers to using the network interface on a system to monitor or capture information sent over a wired or wireless connection.
An adversary may place a network interface into promiscuous mode to passively access data in transit over the network, or use span ports to capture a larger amount of data.
lnx_auditd_network_sniffing.yml.author: Timur Zinniatullin, oscd.community
falsepositives: Legitimate administrator or user uses network sniffing tool for legitimate reasons.

lnx_auditd_omigod_scx_runasprovider_exec.title: OMIGOD SCX RunAsProvider ExecuteShellCommand - Auditd
lnx_auditd_omigod_scx_runasprovider_exec.status:
Rule to detect the use of the SCX RunAsProvider Invoke_ExecuteShellCommand to execute any UNIX/Linux command using the /bin/sh shell.
SCXcore, started as the Microsoft Operations Manager UNIX/Linux Agent, is now used in a host of products including Microsoft Operations Manager.
Microsoft Azure, and Microsoft Operations Management Suite.
lnx_auditd_omigod_scx_runasprovider_exec.description:
Rule to detect the use of the SCX RunAsProvider Invoke_ExecuteShellCommand to execute any UNIX/Linux command using the /bin/sh shell.
SCXcore, started as the Microsoft Operations Manager UNIX/Linux Agent, is now used in a host of products including Microsoft Operations Manager.
Microsoft Azure, and Microsoft Operations Management Suite.
lnx_auditd_omigod_scx_runasprovider_exec.author: Roberto Rodriguez (Cyb3rWard0g), OTR (Open Threat Research)
falsepositives: Legitimate use of SCX RunAsProvider Invoke_ExecuteShellCommand.

ImageMagick must be installed.

lnx_auditd_susp_c2_commands.yml.title: Suspicious C2 Activities
lnx_auditd_susp_c2_commands.yml.status:
Detects suspicious activities as declared by Florian Roth in its 'Best Practice Auditd Configuration'.
This includes the detection of the following commands; wget, curl, base64, nc, netcat, ncat, ssh, socat, wireshark, rawshark, rdesktop, nmap.
These commands match a few techniques from the tactics "Command and Control", including not exhaustively the following; Application Layer Protocol (T1071), Non-Application Layer Protocol (T1095), Data Encoding (T1132)
lnx_auditd_susp_c2_commands.yml.description:
Detects suspicious activities as declared by Florian Roth in its 'Best Practice Auditd Configuration'.
This includes the detection of the following commands; wget, curl, base64, nc, netcat, ncat, ssh, socat, wireshark, rawshark, rdesktop, nmap.
These commands match a few techniques from the tactics "Command and Control", including not exhaustively the following; Application Layer Protocol (T1071), Non-Application Layer Protocol (T1095), Data Encoding (T1132)
lnx_auditd_susp_c2_commands.yml.author: Marie Euler

Detects usage of the 'crontab' utility to remove the current crontab.
This is a common occurrence where cryptocurrency miners compete against each other by removing traces of other miners to hijack the maximum amount of resources possible
proc_creation_lnx_crontab_removal.yml.description:

proc_creation_lnx_omigod_scx_runasprovid.title: OMIGOD SCX RunAsProvider ExecuteScript
proc_creation_lnx_omigod_scx_runasprovid.status:
Rule to detect the use of the SCX RunAsProvider ExecuteScript to execute any UNIX/Linux script using the /bin/sh shell.
Script being executed gets created as a temp file in /tmp folder with a scx* prefix.
Then it is invoked from the following directory /etc/opt/microsoft/scx/conf/tmpdir/.
The file in that directory has the same prefix scx*. SCXcore, started as the Microsoft Operations Manager UNIX/Linux Agent, is now used in a host of products including
Microsoft Operations Manager, Microsoft Azure, and Microsoft Operations Management Suite.
proc_creation_lnx_omigod_scx_runasprovid.description:
Rule to detect the use of the SCX RunAsProvider ExecuteScript to execute any UNIX/Linux script using the /bin/sh shell.
Script being executed gets created as a temp file in /tmp folder with a scx* prefix.
Then it is invoked from the following directory /etc/opt/microsoft/scx/conf/tmpdir/.
The file in that directory has the same prefix scx*. SCXcore, started as the Microsoft Operations Manager UNIX/Linux Agent, is now used in a host of products including
Microsoft Operations Manager, Microsoft Azure, and Microsoft Operations Management Suite.
proc_creation_lnx_omigod_scx_runasprovid.author: Roberto Rodriguez (Cyb3rWard0g), OTR (Open Threat Research), MSTIC
falsepositives: Legitimate use of SCX RunAsProvider ExecuteScript.

proc_creation_lnx_omigod_scx_runasprovid.status:
Rule to detect the use of the SCX RunAsProvider Invoke_ExecuteShellCommand to execute any UNIX/Linux command using the /bin/sh shell.
SCXcore, started as the Microsoft Operations Manager UNIX/Linux Agent, is now used in a host of products including
Microsoft Operations Manager, Microsoft Azure, and Microsoft Operations Management Suite.

proc_creation_lnx_php_reverse_shell.yml.title: Potential PHP Reverse Shell
proc_creation_lnx_php_reverse_shell.yml.status:
Detects usage of the PHP CLI with the "-r" flag which allows it to run inline PHP code. The rule looks for calls to the "fsockopen" function which allows the creation of sockets.
Attackers often leverage this in combination with functions such as "exec" or "fopen" to initiate a reverse shell connection.

proc_creation_macos_payload_decoded_and_.title: Payload Decoded and Decrypted via Built-in Utilities
proc_creation_macos_payload_decoded_and_.status: Detects when a built-in utility is used to decode and decrypt a payload after a macOS disk image (DMG) is executed. Malware authors may attempt to evade detection and trick users into executing malicious code by encoding and encrypting their payload and placing it in a disk image file. This behavior is consistent with adware or malware families such as Bundlore and Shlayer.
proc_creation_macos_payload_decoded_and_.description: Detects when a built-in utility is used to decode and decrypt a payload after a macOS disk image (DMG) is executed. Malware authors may attempt to evade detection and trick users into executing malicious code by encoding and encrypting their payload and placing it in a disk image file. This behavior is consistent with adware or malware families such as Bundlore and Shlayer.

zeek_dce_rpc_potential_petit_potam_efs_r.title: Potential PetitPotam Attack Via EFS RPC Calls
zeek_dce_rpc_potential_petit_potam_efs_r.status:
Detects usage of the windows RPC library Encrypting File System Remote Protocol (MS-EFSRPC). Variations of this RPC are used within the attack refereed to as PetitPotam.
The usage of this RPC function should be rare if ever used at all.
Thus usage of this function is uncommon enough that any usage of this RPC function should warrant further investigation to determine if it is legitimate.
 View surrounding logs (within a few minutes before and after) from the Source IP to. Logs from from the Source IP would include dce_rpc, smb_mapping, smb_files, rdp, ntlm, kerberos, etc..'
zeek_dce_rpc_potential_petit_potam_efs_r.description:
Detects usage of the windows RPC library Encrypting File System Remote Protocol (MS-EFSRPC). Variations of this RPC are used within the attack refereed to as PetitPotam.
The usage of this RPC function should be rare if ever used at all.
Thus usage of this function is uncommon enough that any usage of this RPC function should warrant further investigation to determine if it is legitimate.
 View surrounding logs (within a few minutes before and after) from the Source IP to. Logs from from the Source IP would include dce_rpc, smb_mapping, smb_files, rdp, ntlm, kerberos, etc..'
zeek_dce_rpc_potential_petit_potam_efs_r.author: @neu5ron, @Antonlovesdnb, Mike Remen
falsepositives: Uncommon but legitimate windows administrator or software tasks that make use of the Encrypting File System RPC Calls. Verify if this is common activity (see description).

zeek_dce_rpc_printnightmare_print_driver.title: Possible PrintNightmare Print Driver Install
zeek_dce_rpc_printnightmare_print_driver.status:
Detects the remote installation of a print driver which is possible indication of the exploitation of PrintNightmare (CVE-2021-1675).
The occurrence of print drivers being installed remotely via RPC functions should be rare, as print drivers are normally installed locally and or through group policy.
zeek_dce_rpc_printnightmare_print_driver.description:
Detects the remote installation of a print driver which is possible indication of the exploitation of PrintNightmare (CVE-2021-1675).
The occurrence of print drivers being installed remotely via RPC functions should be rare, as print drivers are normally installed locally and or through group policy.
zeek_dce_rpc_printnightmare_print_driver.author: @neu5ron (Nate Guagenti)
falsepositives: Legitimate remote alteration of a printer driver.

falsepositives: A DNS lookup does not necessarily  mean a successful attempt, verify a) if there was a response using the zeek answers field, if there was then verify the connections (conn.log) to those IPs. b) verify if HTTP, SSL, or TLS activity to the domain that was queried. http.log field is 'host' and ssl/tls is 'server_name'.

zeek_dns_susp_zbit_flag.yml.title: Suspicious DNS Z Flag Bit Set
zeek_dns_susp_zbit_flag.yml.status:
The DNS Z flag is bit within the DNS protocol header that is, per the IETF design, meant to be used reserved (unused).
Although recently it has been used in DNSSec, the value being set to anything other than 0 should be rare.
Otherwise if it is set to non 0 and DNSSec is being used, then excluding the legitimate domains is low effort and high reward.
Determine if multiple of these files were accessed in a short period of time to further enhance the possibility of seeing if this was a one off or the possibility of larger sensitive file gathering.
This Sigma query is designed to accompany the Corelight Threat Hunting Guide, which can be found here: https://www3.corelight.com/corelights-introductory-guide-to-threat-hunting-with-zeek-bro-logs'
zeek_dns_susp_zbit_flag.yml.description:
The DNS Z flag is bit within the DNS protocol header that is, per the IETF design, meant to be used reserved (unused).
Although recently it has been used in DNSSec, the value being set to anything other than 0 should be rare.
Otherwise if it is set to non 0 and DNSSec is being used, then excluding the legitimate domains is low effort and high reward.
Determine if multiple of these files were accessed in a short period of time to further enhance the possibility of seeing if this was a one off or the possibility of larger sensitive file gathering.
This Sigma query is designed to accompany the Corelight Threat Hunting Guide, which can be found here: https://www3.corelight.com/corelights-introductory-guide-to-threat-hunting-with-zeek-bro-logs'
zeek_dns_susp_zbit_flag.yml.author: @neu5ron, SOC Prime Team, Corelight

detection.condition: not z_flag_unset and most_probable_valid_domain and not (exclude_tlds or exclude_query_types or exclude_responses or exclude_netbios)

falsepositives: Internal or legitimate external domains using DNSSec. Verify if these are legitimate DNSSec domains and then exclude them.
If you work in a Public Sector then it may be good to exclude things like endswith ".edu", ".gov" and or ".mil"

zeek_http_omigod_no_auth_rce.yml.title: OMIGOD HTTP No Authentication RCE
zeek_http_omigod_no_auth_rce.yml.status:
Detects the exploitation of OMIGOD (CVE-2021-38647) which allows remote execute (RCE) commands as root with just a single unauthenticated HTTP request.
Verify, successful, exploitation by viewing the HTTP client (request) body to see what was passed to the server (using PCAP).
Within the client body is where the code execution would occur. Additionally, check the endpoint logs to see if suspicious commands or activity occurred within the timeframe of this HTTP request.
zeek_http_omigod_no_auth_rce.yml.description:
Detects the exploitation of OMIGOD (CVE-2021-38647) which allows remote execute (RCE) commands as root with just a single unauthenticated HTTP request.
Verify, successful, exploitation by viewing the HTTP client (request) body to see what was passed to the server (using PCAP).
Within the client body is where the code execution would occur. Additionally, check the endpoint logs to see if suspicious commands or activity occurred within the timeframe of this HTTP request.
zeek_http_omigod_no_auth_rce.yml.author: Nate Guagenti (neu5ron)

logsource.definition: Enable the builtin Zeek script that logs all HTTP header names by adding "@load policy/protocols/http/header-names" to your local.zeek config file. The script can be seen here for reference https://github.com/zeek/zeek/blob/d957f883df242ef159cfd846884e673addeea7a5/scripts/policy/protocols/http/header-names.zeek

detection.condition: selection and not auth_header and not too_small_http_client_body

falsepositives: Exploits that were attempted but unsuccessful.

Scanning attempts with the abnormal use of the HTTP POST method with no indication of code execution within the HTTP Client (Request) body. An example would be vulnerability scanners trying to identify unpatched versions while not actually exploiting the vulnerability. See description for investigation tips.

win_codeintegrity_attempted_dll_load.yml.title: CodeIntegrity - Unmet Signing Level Requirements By File Under Validation
win_codeintegrity_attempted_dll_load.yml.status:
Detects attempted file load events that did not meet the signing level requirements. It often means the file's signature is revoked or a signature with the Lifetime Signing EKU has expired.
This event is best correlated with EID 3089 to determine the error of the validation.
win_codeintegrity_attempted_dll_load.yml.description:
Detects attempted file load events that did not meet the signing level requirements. It often means the file's signature is revoked or a signature with the Lifetime Signing EKU has expired.
This event is best correlated with EID 3089 to determine the error of the validation.
win_codeintegrity_attempted_dll_load.yml.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

detection.condition: selection and not 1 of filter_main_* and not 1 of filter_optional_*

falsepositives: Antivirus and other third party products are known to trigger this rule quite a lot. Initial filters and tuning is required before using this rule.

win_security_aadhealth_mon_agent_regkey_.title: Azure AD Health Monitoring Agent Registry Keys Access
win_security_aadhealth_mon_agent_regkey_.status:
This detection uses Windows security events to detect suspicious access attempts to the registry key of Azure AD Health monitoring agent.
This detection requires an access control entry (ACE) on the system access control list (SACL) of the following securable object HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Microsoft Online\Reporting\MonitoringAgent.
win_security_aadhealth_mon_agent_regkey_.description:
This detection uses Windows security events to detect suspicious access attempts to the registry key of Azure AD Health monitoring agent.
This detection requires an access control entry (ACE) on the system access control list (SACL) of the following securable object HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Microsoft Online\Reporting\MonitoringAgent.
win_security_aadhealth_mon_agent_regkey_.author: Roberto Rodriguez (Cyb3rWard0g), OTR (Open Threat Research), MSTIC

win_security_aadhealth_svc_agent_regkey_.title: Azure AD Health Service Agents Registry Keys Access
win_security_aadhealth_svc_agent_regkey_.status:
This detection uses Windows security events to detect suspicious access attempts to the registry key values and sub-keys of Azure AD Health service agents (e.g AD FS).
Information from AD Health service agents can be used to potentially abuse some of the features provided by those services in the cloud (e.g. Federation).
This detection requires an access control entry (ACE) on the system access control list (SACL) of the following securable object: HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\ADHealthAgent.
Make sure you set the SACL to propagate to its sub-keys.
win_security_aadhealth_svc_agent_regkey_.description:
This detection uses Windows security events to detect suspicious access attempts to the registry key values and sub-keys of Azure AD Health service agents (e.g AD FS).
Information from AD Health service agents can be used to potentially abuse some of the features provided by those services in the cloud (e.g. Federation).
This detection requires an access control entry (ACE) on the system access control list (SACL) of the following securable object: HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\ADHealthAgent.
Make sure you set the SACL to propagate to its sub-keys.
win_security_aadhealth_svc_agent_regkey_.author: Roberto Rodriguez (Cyb3rWard0g), OTR (Open Threat Research), MSTIC

win_security_account_backdoor_dcsync_rig.author: Samir Bousseaden; Roberto Rodriguez @Cyb3rWard0g; oscd.community; Tim Shelton; Maxence Fossat

logsource.definition: The "Audit Directory Service Changes" logging policy must be configured in order to receive events. Audit events are generated only for objects with configured system access control lists (SACLs). Audit events are generated only for objects with configured system access control lists (SACLs) and only when accessed in a manner that matches their SACL settings. This policy covers the following events ids - 5136, 5137, 5138, 5139, 5141. Note that the default policy does not cover User objects. For that a custom AuditRule need to be setup (See https://github.com/OTRF/Set-AuditRule)

falsepositives: New Domain Controller computer account, check user SIDs within the value attribute of event 5136 and verify if it's a regular user or DC computer account.

win_security_disable_event_auditing.yml.title: Windows Event Auditing Disabled
win_security_disable_event_auditing.yml.status:
Detects scenarios where system auditing (i.e.: Windows event log auditing) is disabled.
This may be used in a scenario where an entity would want to bypass local logging to evade detection when Windows event logging is enabled and reviewed.
Also, it is recommended to turn off "Local Group Policy Object Processing" via GPO, which will make sure that Active Directory GPOs take precedence over local/edited computer policies via something such as "gpedit.msc".
Please note, that disabling "Local Group Policy Object Processing" may cause an issue in scenarios of one off specific GPO modifications - however, it is recommended to perform these modifications in Active Directory anyways.
win_security_disable_event_auditing.yml.description:
Detects scenarios where system auditing (i.e.: Windows event log auditing) is disabled.
This may be used in a scenario where an entity would want to bypass local logging to evade detection when Windows event logging is enabled and reviewed.
Also, it is recommended to turn off "Local Group Policy Object Processing" via GPO, which will make sure that Active Directory GPOs take precedence over local/edited computer policies via something such as "gpedit.msc".
Please note, that disabling "Local Group Policy Object Processing" may cause an issue in scenarios of one off specific GPO modifications - however, it is recommended to perform these modifications in Active Directory anyways.
win_security_disable_event_auditing.yml.author: @neu5ron, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

win_security_petitpotam_susp_tgt_request.title: PetitPotam Suspicious Kerberos TGT Request
win_security_petitpotam_susp_tgt_request.status:
Detect suspicious Kerberos TGT requests.
Once an attacer obtains a computer certificate by abusing Active Directory Certificate Services in combination with PetitPotam, the next step would be to leverage the certificate for malicious purposes.
One way of doing this is to request a Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket using a tool like Rubeus.
This request will generate a 4768 event with some unusual fields depending on the environment.
This analytic will require tuning, we recommend filtering Account_Name to the Domain Controller computer accounts.
win_security_petitpotam_susp_tgt_request.description:
Detect suspicious Kerberos TGT requests.
Once an attacer obtains a computer certificate by abusing Active Directory Certificate Services in combination with PetitPotam, the next step would be to leverage the certificate for malicious purposes.
One way of doing this is to request a Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket using a tool like Rubeus.
This request will generate a 4768 event with some unusual fields depending on the environment.
This analytic will require tuning, we recommend filtering Account_Name to the Domain Controller computer accounts.
win_security_petitpotam_susp_tgt_request.author: Mauricio Velazco, Michael Haag

logsource.definition: The advanced audit policy setting "Account Logon > Kerberos Authentication Service" must be configured for Success/Failure

falsepositives: False positives are possible if the environment is using certificates for authentication. We recommend filtering Account_Name to the Domain Controller computer accounts.

logsource.definition: The "Audit Directory Service Changes" logging policy must be configured in order to receive events. Audit events are generated only for objects with configured system access control lists (SACLs). Audit events are generated only for objects with configured system access control lists (SACLs) and only when accessed in a manner that matches their SACL settings. This policy covers the following events ids - 5136, 5137, 5138, 5139, 5141. Note that the default policy does not cover User objects. For that a custom AuditRule need to be setup (See https://github.com/OTRF/Set-AuditRule)

falsepositives: Valid on domain controllers; exclude known DCs

win_security_registry_permissions_weakne.title: Service Registry Key Read Access Request
win_security_registry_permissions_weakne.status:
Detects "read access" requests on the services registry key.
Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the Registry entries used by services.
Adversaries may use flaws in the permissions for Registry keys related to services to redirect from the originally specified executable to one that they control, in order to launch their own code when a service starts.
win_security_registry_permissions_weakne.description:
Detects "read access" requests on the services registry key.
Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the Registry entries used by services.
Adversaries may use flaws in the permissions for Registry keys related to services to redirect from the originally specified executable to one that they control, in order to launch their own code when a service starts.
win_security_registry_permissions_weakne.author: Center for Threat Informed Defense (CTID) Summiting the Pyramid Team

logsource.definition: Requirements: SACLs must be enabled for "READ_CONTROL" on the registry keys used in this rule

falsepositives: Likely from legitimate applications reading their key. Requires heavy tuning

win_security_user_driver_loaded.yml.title: Potential Privileged System Service Operation - SeLoadDriverPrivilege
win_security_user_driver_loaded.yml.status:
Detects the usage of the 'SeLoadDriverPrivilege' privilege. This privilege is required to load or unload a device driver.
With this privilege, the user can dynamically load and unload device drivers or other code in to kernel mode.
This user right does not apply to Plug and Play device drivers.
If you exclude privileged users/admins and processes, which are allowed to do so, you are maybe left with bad programs trying to load malicious kernel drivers.
This will detect Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs) and the usage of Sysinternals and various other tools. So you have to work with a whitelist to find the bad stuff.
win_security_user_driver_loaded.yml.description:
Detects the usage of the 'SeLoadDriverPrivilege' privilege. This privilege is required to load or unload a device driver.
With this privilege, the user can dynamically load and unload device drivers or other code in to kernel mode.
This user right does not apply to Plug and Play device drivers.
If you exclude privileged users/admins and processes, which are allowed to do so, you are maybe left with bad programs trying to load malicious kernel drivers.
This will detect Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs) and the usage of Sysinternals and various other tools. So you have to work with a whitelist to find the bad stuff.
win_security_user_driver_loaded.yml.author: xknow (@xknow_infosec), xorxes (@xor_xes)
falsepositives: Other legimate tools loading drivers. Including but not limited to, Sysinternals, CPU-Z, AVs etc. A baseline needs to be created according to the used products and allowed tools. A good thing to do is to try and exclude users who are allowed to load drivers.

create_remote_thread_win_mstsc_susp_loca.title: Remote Thread Creation In Mstsc.Exe From Suspicious Location
create_remote_thread_win_mstsc_susp_loca.status:
Detects remote thread creation in the "mstsc.exe" process by a process located in a potentially suspicious location.
This technique is often used by attackers in order to hook some APIs used by DLLs loaded by "mstsc.exe" during RDP authentications in order to steal credentials.

create_remote_thread_win_password_dumper.title: Password Dumper Remote Thread in LSASS
create_remote_thread_win_password_dumper.status:
Detects password dumper activity by monitoring remote thread creation EventID 8 in combination with the lsass.exe process as TargetImage.
The process in field Process is the malicious program. A single execution can lead to hundreds of events.

dns_query_win_remote_access_software_dom.title: DNS Query To Remote Access Software Domain From Non-Browser App
dns_query_win_remote_access_software_dom.status:
An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks.
These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment.
Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)
dns_query_win_remote_access_software_dom.description:
An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks.
These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment.
Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)
dns_query_win_remote_access_software_dom.author: frack113, Connor Martin

detection.condition: 1 of selection_* and not 1 of filter_optional_*

falsepositives: Likely with other browser software. Apply additional filters for any other browsers you might use.

Detects file access requests to browser credential stores by uncommon processes.
Could indicate potential attempt of credential stealing.
Requires heavy baselining before usage

detection.condition: 1 of selection_* and not 1 of filter_main_* and not 1 of filter_optional_*

falsepositives: Legitimate software installed on partitions other than "C:\"

file_access_win_credential_manager_acces.title: Credential Manager Access By Uncommon Application
file_access_win_credential_manager_acces.status:
Detects suspicious processes based on name and location that access the windows credential manager and vault.
Which can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::cred" function

file_change_win_2022_timestomping.yml.title: File Creation Date Changed to Another Year
file_change_win_2022_timestomping.yml.status:
Attackers may change the file creation time of a backdoor to make it look like it was installed with the operating system.
Note that many processes legitimately change the creation time of a file; it does not necessarily indicate malicious activity.

file_event_win_access_susp_unattend_xml..status:

If these files exist, their contents will be displayed. They are used to store credentials/answers during the unattended windows install process

file_event_win_anydesk_artefact.yml.title: Anydesk Temporary Artefact
file_event_win_anydesk_artefact.yml.status:
An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks.
These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment.
Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)
file_event_win_anydesk_artefact.yml.description:
An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks.
These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment.
Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)
file_event_win_anydesk_artefact.yml.author: frack113

file_event_win_anydesk_writing_susp_bina.title: Suspicious Binary Writes Via AnyDesk
file_event_win_anydesk_writing_susp_bina.status:
Detects AnyDesk writing binary files to disk other than "gcapi.dll".
According to RedCanary research it is highly abnormal for AnyDesk to write executable files to disk besides gcapi.dll,
which is a legitimate DLL that is part of the Google Chrome web browser used to interact with the Google Cloud API. (See reference section for more details)
file_event_win_anydesk_writing_susp_bina.description:

file_event_win_anydesk_writing_susp_bina.author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

file_event_win_creation_new_shim_databas.title: New Shim Database Created in the Default Directory
file_event_win_creation_new_shim_databas.status:
Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by application shims.
The Microsoft Windows Application Compatibility Infrastructure/Framework (Application Shim) was created to allow for backward compatibility of software as the operating system codebase changes over time.
file_event_win_creation_new_shim_databas.description:
Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by application shims.
The Microsoft Windows Application Compatibility Infrastructure/Framework (Application Shim) was created to allow for backward compatibility of software as the operating system codebase changes over time.
file_event_win_creation_new_shim_databas.author: frack113, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
falsepositives: Legitimate custom SHIM installations will also trigger this rule

file_event_win_creation_scr_binary_file..title: Suspicious Screensaver Binary File Creation
file_event_win_creation_scr_binary_file..status:
Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by user inactivity.
Screensavers are programs that execute after a configurable time of user inactivity and consist of Portable Executable (PE) files with a .scr file extension
file_event_win_creation_scr_binary_file..description:
Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by user inactivity.
Screensavers are programs that execute after a configurable time of user inactivity and consist of Portable Executable (PE) files with a .scr file extension
file_event_win_creation_scr_binary_file..author: frack113

file_event_win_creation_unquoted_service.title: Creation Exe for Service with Unquoted Path
file_event_win_creation_unquoted_service.status:
Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking vulnerable file path references.
Adversaries can take advantage of paths that lack surrounding quotations by placing an executable in a higher level directory within the path, so that Windows will choose the adversary's executable to launch.
file_event_win_creation_unquoted_service.description:

Adversaries can take advantage of paths that lack surrounding quotations by placing an executable in a higher level directory within the path, so that Windows will choose the adversary's executable to launch.
file_event_win_creation_unquoted_service.author: frack113

file_event_win_csharp_compile_artefact.y.title: Dynamic CSharp Compile Artefact
file_event_win_csharp_compile_artefact.y.status:
When C# is compiled dynamically, a .cmdline file will be created as a part of the process.
Certain processes are not typically observed compiling C# code, but can do so without touching disk.
This can be used to unpack a payload for execution
file_event_win_csharp_compile_artefact.y.description:

Certain processes are not typically observed compiling C# code, but can do so without touching disk.
This can be used to unpack a payload for execution

file_event_win_dll_sideloading_space_pat.title: DLL Search Order Hijackig Via Additional Space in Path
file_event_win_dll_sideloading_space_pat.status:
Detects when an attacker create a similar folder structure to windows system folders such as (Windows, Program Files...)
but with a space in order to trick DLL load search order and perform a "DLL Search Order Hijacking" attack
file_event_win_dll_sideloading_space_pat.description:

file_event_win_dump_file_creation.yml.title: DMP/HDMP File Creation
file_event_win_dump_file_creation.yml.status: Detects the creation of a file with the ".dmp"/".hdmp" extension. Often created by software during a crash. Memory dumps can sometimes contain sensitive information such as credentials. It's best to determin the source of the crash.
file_event_win_dump_file_creation.yml.description: Detects the creation of a file with the ".dmp"/".hdmp" extension. Often created by software during a crash. Memory dumps can sometimes contain sensitive information such as credentials. It's best to determin the source of the crash.

file_event_win_dump_file_susp_creation.y.title: Potentially Suspicious DMP/HDMP File Creation
file_event_win_dump_file_susp_creation.y.status: Detects the creation of a file with the ".dmp"/".hdmp" extension by a shell or scripting application such as "cmd", "powershell", etc. Often created by software during a crash. Memory dumps can sometimes contain sensitive information such as credentials. It's best to determine the source of the crash.
file_event_win_dump_file_susp_creation.y.description: Detects the creation of a file with the ".dmp"/".hdmp" extension by a shell or scripting application such as "cmd", "powershell", etc. Often created by software during a crash. Memory dumps can sometimes contain sensitive information such as credentials. It's best to determine the source of the crash.
file_event_win_dump_file_susp_creation.y.author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
falsepositives: Some administrative PowerShell or VB scripts might have the ability to collect dumps and move them to other folders which might trigger a false positive.

file_event_win_errorhandler_persistence..title: Potential Persistence Attempt Via ErrorHandler.Cmd
file_event_win_errorhandler_persistence..status:
Detects creation of a file named "ErrorHandler.cmd" in the "C:\WINDOWS\Setup\Scripts\" directory which could be used as a method of persistence
The content of C:\WINDOWS\Setup\Scripts\ErrorHandler.cmd is read whenever some tools under C:\WINDOWS\System32\oobe\ (e.g. Setup.exe) fail to run for any reason.
file_event_win_errorhandler_persistence..description:

file_event_win_gotoopener_artefact.yml.title: GoToAssist Temporary Installation Artefact
file_event_win_gotoopener_artefact.yml.status:
An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks.
These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment.
Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)
file_event_win_gotoopener_artefact.yml.description:
An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks.
These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment.
Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)
file_event_win_gotoopener_artefact.yml.author: frack113

file_event_win_hktl_powerup_dllhijacking.title: Powerup Write Hijack DLL
file_event_win_hktl_powerup_dllhijacking.status:
Powerup tool's Write Hijack DLL exploits DLL hijacking for privilege escalation.
In it's default mode, it builds a self deleting .bat file which executes malicious command.
The detection rule relies on creation of the malicious bat file (debug.bat by default).
file_event_win_hktl_powerup_dllhijacking.description:
Powerup tool's Write Hijack DLL exploits DLL hijacking for privilege escalation.
In it's default mode, it builds a self deleting .bat file which executes malicious command.
The detection rule relies on creation of the malicious bat file (debug.bat by default).

falsepositives: Any powershell script that creates bat files

file_event_win_iso_file_recent.yml.title: ISO or Image Mount Indicator in Recent Files
file_event_win_iso_file_recent.yml.status:
Detects the creation of recent element file that points to an .ISO, .IMG, .VHD or .VHDX file as often used in phishing attacks.
This can be a false positive on server systems but on workstations users should rarely mount .iso or .img files.
file_event_win_iso_file_recent.yml.description:
Detects the creation of recent element file that points to an .ISO, .IMG, .VHD or .VHDX file as often used in phishing attacks.
This can be a false positive on server systems but on workstations users should rarely mount .iso or .img files.
file_event_win_iso_file_recent.yml.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)
falsepositives: Cases in which a user mounts an image file for legitimate reasons

file_event_win_powershell_startup_shortc.title: Potential Startup Shortcut Persistence Via PowerShell.EXE
file_event_win_powershell_startup_shortc.status:
Detects PowerShell writing startup shortcuts.
This procedure was highlighted in Red Canary Intel Insights Oct. 2021, "We frequently observe adversaries using PowerShell to write malicious .lnk files into the startup directory to establish persistence.
Accordingly, this detection opportunity is likely to identify persistence mechanisms in multiple threats.
In the context of Yellow Cockatoo, this persistence mechanism eventually launches the command-line script that leads to the installation of a malicious DLL"
file_event_win_powershell_startup_shortc.description:
Detects PowerShell writing startup shortcuts.
This procedure was highlighted in Red Canary Intel Insights Oct. 2021, "We frequently observe adversaries using PowerShell to write malicious .lnk files into the startup directory to establish persistence.
Accordingly, this detection opportunity is likely to identify persistence mechanisms in multiple threats.
In the context of Yellow Cockatoo, this persistence mechanism eventually launches the command-line script that leads to the installation of a malicious DLL"
file_event_win_powershell_startup_shortc.author: Christopher Peacock '@securepeacock', SCYTHE
falsepositives: Depending on your environment accepted applications may leverage this at times. It is recommended to search for anomalies inidicative of malware.

file_event_win_remote_access_tools_scree.title: ScreenConnect Temporary Installation Artefact
file_event_win_remote_access_tools_scree.status:
An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks.
These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment.
Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)
file_event_win_remote_access_tools_scree.description:
An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks.
These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment.
Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)
file_event_win_remote_access_tools_scree.author: frack113

file_event_win_remote_access_tools_scree.title: Remote Access Tool - ScreenConnect Temporary File
file_event_win_remote_access_tools_scree.status:
Detects the creation of files in a specific location by ScreenConnect RMM.
ScreenConnect has feature to remotely execute binaries on a target machine. These binaries will be dropped to ":\Users\<username>\Documents\ConnectWiseControl\Temp\" before execution.
file_event_win_remote_access_tools_scree.description:
Detects the creation of files in a specific location by ScreenConnect RMM.

file_event_win_ripzip_attack.yml.title: Potential RipZip Attack on Startup Folder
file_event_win_ripzip_attack.yml.status:
Detects a phishing attack which expands a ZIP file containing a malicious shortcut.
If the victim expands the ZIP file via the explorer process, then the explorer process expands the malicious ZIP file and drops a malicious shortcut redirected to a backdoor into the Startup folder.
Additionally, the file name of the malicious shortcut in Startup folder contains {0AFACED1-E828-11D1-9187-B532F1E9575D} meaning the folder shortcut operation.

file_event_win_susp_get_variable.yml.title: Suspicious Get-Variable.exe Creation
file_event_win_susp_get_variable.yml.status:
Get-Variable is a valid PowerShell cmdlet
WindowsApps is by default in the path where PowerShell is executed.
So when the Get-Variable command is issued on PowerShell execution, the system first looks for the Get-Variable executable in the path and executes the malicious binary instead of looking for the PowerShell cmdlet.

file_event_win_susp_homoglyph_filename.y.title: Potential Homoglyph Attack Using Lookalike Characters in Filename
file_event_win_susp_homoglyph_filename.y.status:
Detects the presence of unicode characters which are homoglyphs, or identical in appearance, to ASCII letter characters.
This is used as an obfuscation and masquerading techniques. Only "perfect" homoglyphs are included; these are characters that
are indistinguishable from ASCII characters and thus may make excellent candidates for homoglyph attack characters.

This is used as an obfuscation and masquerading techniques. Only "perfect" homoglyphs are included; these are characters that
are indistinguishable from ASCII characters and thus may make excellent candidates for homoglyph attack characters.
file_event_win_susp_homoglyph_filename.y.author: Micah Babinski, @micahbabinski
falsepositives: File names with legitimate Cyrillic text. Will likely require tuning (or not be usable) in countries where these alphabets are in use.

file_event_win_susp_procexplorer_driver_.title: Suspicious PROCEXP152.sys File Created In TMP
file_event_win_susp_procexplorer_driver_.status:
Detects the creation of the PROCEXP152.sys file in the application-data local temporary folder.
This driver is used by Sysinternals Process Explorer but also by KDU (https://github.com/hfiref0x/KDU) or Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs), which uses KDU.
file_event_win_susp_procexplorer_driver_.description:
Detects the creation of the PROCEXP152.sys file in the application-data local temporary folder.
This driver is used by Sysinternals Process Explorer but also by KDU (https://github.com/hfiref0x/KDU) or Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs), which uses KDU.
file_event_win_susp_procexplorer_driver_.author: xknow (@xknow_infosec), xorxes (@xor_xes)
falsepositives: Other legimate tools using this driver and filename (like Sysinternals). Note - Clever attackers may easily bypass this detection by just renaming the driver filename. Therefore just Medium-level and don't rely on it.

file_event_win_sysinternals_procexp_driv.title: Process Explorer Driver Creation By Non-Sysinternals Binary
file_event_win_sysinternals_procexp_driv.status:
Detects creation of the Process Explorer drivers by processes other than Process Explorer (procexp) itself.
Hack tools or malware may use the Process Explorer driver to elevate privileges, drops it to disk for a few moments, runs a service using that driver and removes it afterwards.
file_event_win_sysinternals_procexp_driv.description:
Detects creation of the Process Explorer drivers by processes other than Process Explorer (procexp) itself.
Hack tools or malware may use the Process Explorer driver to elevate privileges, drops it to disk for a few moments, runs a service using that driver and removes it afterwards.
file_event_win_sysinternals_procexp_driv.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)
falsepositives: Some false positives may occur with legitimate renamed process explorer binaries

Malware can use mountable Virtual Hard Disk ".vhd" files to encapsulate payloads and evade security controls.

image_load_dll_azure_microsoft_account_t.title: Potential Azure Browser SSO Abuse
image_load_dll_azure_microsoft_account_t.status:
Detects abusing Azure Browser SSO by requesting OAuth 2.0 refresh tokens for an Azure-AD-authenticated Windows user (i.e. the machine is joined to Azure AD and a user logs in with their Azure AD account) wanting to perform SSO authentication in the browser.
An attacker can use this to authenticate to Azure AD in a browser as that user.
image_load_dll_azure_microsoft_account_t.description:
Detects abusing Azure Browser SSO by requesting OAuth 2.0 refresh tokens for an Azure-AD-authenticated Windows user (i.e. the machine is joined to Azure AD and a user logs in with their Azure AD account) wanting to perform SSO authentication in the browser.
An attacker can use this to authenticate to Azure AD in a browser as that user.
image_load_dll_azure_microsoft_account_t.author: Den Iuzvyk

detection.condition: selection and not 1 of filter_main_* and not 1 of filter_optional_*

falsepositives: False positives are expected since this rules is only looking for the DLL load event. This rule is better used in correlation with related activity

image_load_dll_credui_uncommon_process_l.description: Detects loading of "credui.dll" and related DLLs by an uncommon process. Attackers might leverage this DLL for potential use of "CredUIPromptForCredentials" or "CredUnPackAuthenticationBufferW".

detection.condition: selection and not 1 of filter_main_* and not 1 of filter_optional_*

falsepositives: Other legitimate processes loading those DLLs in your environment.

image_load_dll_dbghelp_dbgcore_susp_load.status:
Detects the load of dbghelp/dbgcore DLL (used to make memory dumps) by suspicious processes.
Tools like ProcessHacker and some attacker tradecraft use MiniDumpWriteDump API found in dbghelp.dll or dbgcore.dll.
As an example, SilentTrynity C2 Framework has a module that leverages this API to dump the contents of Lsass.exe and transfer it over the network back to the attacker's machine.
image_load_dll_dbghelp_dbgcore_susp_load.description:

image_load_side_load_shell_chrome_api.ym.title: DLL Sideloading Of ShellChromeAPI.DLL
image_load_side_load_shell_chrome_api.ym.status:
Detects processes loading the non-existent DLL "ShellChromeAPI". One known example is the "DeviceEnroller" binary in combination with the "PhoneDeepLink" flag tries to load this DLL.
Adversaries can drop their own renamed DLL and execute it via DeviceEnroller.exe using this parameter

image_load_side_load_svchost_dlls.yml.title: Svchost DLL Search Order Hijack
image_load_side_load_svchost_dlls.yml.status:
Detects DLL sideloading of DLLs that are loaded by the SCM for some services (IKE, IKEEXT, SessionEnv) which do not exists on a typical modern system
IKEEXT and SessionEnv service, as they call LoadLibrary on files that do not exist within C:\Windows\System32\ by default.
An attacker can place their malicious logic within the PROCESS_ATTACH block of their library and restart the aforementioned services "svchost.exe -k netsvcs" to gain code execution on a remote machine.
image_load_side_load_svchost_dlls.yml.description:
Detects DLL sideloading of DLLs that are loaded by the SCM for some services (IKE, IKEEXT, SessionEnv) which do not exists on a typical modern system
IKEEXT and SessionEnv service, as they call LoadLibrary on files that do not exist within C:\Windows\System32\ by default.
An attacker can place their malicious logic within the PROCESS_ATTACH block of their library and restart the aforementioned services "svchost.exe -k netsvcs" to gain code execution on a remote machine.
image_load_side_load_svchost_dlls.yml.author: SBousseaden

Since the ImageLoad event doesn't have enough information in this case. It's better to look at the recent process creation events that spawned the WMIC process and investigate the command line and parent/child processes to get more insights

net_connection_win_excel_outbound_networ.title: Excel Network Connections
net_connection_win_excel_outbound_networ.status:
Detects an Excel process that opens suspicious network connections to non-private IP addresses, and attempts to cover CVE-2021-42292.
You will likely have to tune this rule for your organization, but it is certainly something you should look for and could have applications for malicious activity beyond CVE-2021-42292.
net_connection_win_excel_outbound_networ.description:
Detects an Excel process that opens suspicious network connections to non-private IP addresses, and attempts to cover CVE-2021-42292.
You will likely have to tune this rule for your organization, but it is certainly something you should look for and could have applications for malicious activity beyond CVE-2021-42292.
net_connection_win_excel_outbound_networ.author: Christopher Peacock '@securepeacock', SCYTHE '@scythe_io', Florian Roth '@Neo23x0", Tim Shelton
falsepositives: You may have to tune certain domains out that Excel may call out to, such as microsoft or other business use case domains.
Office documents commonly have templates that refer to external addresses, like sharepoint.ourcompany.com may have to be tuned.
It is highly recommended to baseline your activity and tune out common business use cases.

net_connection_win_susp_outbound_smtp_co.title: Suspicious Outbound SMTP Connections
net_connection_win_susp_outbound_smtp_co.status:
Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over an un-encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel.
The data may also be sent to an alternate network location from the main command and control server.
net_connection_win_susp_outbound_smtp_co.description:

The data may also be sent to an alternate network location from the main command and control server.

net_connection_win_wuauclt_network_conne.title: Wuauclt Network Connection
net_connection_win_wuauclt_network_conne.status:
Detects the use of the Windows Update Client binary (wuauclt.exe) to proxy execute code and making a network connections.
One could easily make the DLL spawn a new process and inject to it to proxy the network connection and bypass this rule.
net_connection_win_wuauclt_network_conne.description:
Detects the use of the Windows Update Client binary (wuauclt.exe) to proxy execute code and making a network connections.
One could easily make the DLL spawn a new process and inject to it to proxy the network connection and bypass this rule.
net_connection_win_wuauclt_network_conne.author: Roberto Rodriguez (Cyb3rWard0g), OTR (Open Threat Research)
falsepositives: Legitimate use of wuauclt.exe over the network.
