logsource.definition: Note that you have to configure logging for Named Pipe Events in Sysmon config (Event ID 17 and Event ID 18). The basic configuration is in popular sysmon configuration (https://github.com/SwiftOnSecurity/sysmon-config), but it is worth verifying. You can also use other repo, e.g. https://github.com/Neo23x0/sysmon-config, https://github.com/olafhartong/sysmon-modular. How to test detection? You can check powershell script from this site https://svch0st.medium.com/guide-to-named-pipes-and-hunting-for-cobalt-strike-pipes-dc46b2c5f575

pipe_created_susp_adfs_namedpipe_connect.title: ADFS Database Named Pipe Connection
pipe_created_susp_adfs_namedpipe_connect.status:
Detects suspicious local connections via a named pipe to the AD FS configuration database (Windows Internal Database).
Used to access information such as the AD FS configuration settings which contains sensitive information used to sign SAML tokens.

You can also use other repo, e.g. https://github.com/Neo23x0/sysmon-config, https://github.com/olafhartong/sysmon-modular. How to test detection? You can check powershell script from this site https://svch0st.medium.com/guide-to-named-pipes-and-hunting-for-cobalt-strike-pipes-dc46b2c5f575

focuses on trivial artifacts observed in variants of prevalent offensive ps1 payloads, including
Cobalt Strike Beacon, PoshC2, Powerview, Letmein, Empire, Powersploit, and other attack payloads 
that often undergo minimal changes by attackers due to bad opsec.

posh_pm_susp_ad_group_reco.yml.title: AD Groups Or Users Enumeration Using PowerShell - PoshModule
posh_pm_susp_ad_group_reco.yml.status:
Adversaries may attempt to find domain-level groups and permission settings.
The knowledge of domain-level permission groups can help adversaries determine which groups exist and which users belong to a particular group.
Adversaries may use this information to determine which users have elevated permissions, such as domain administrators.

Adversaries may use this information to determine which users have elevated permissions, such as the users found within the local administrators group.

posh_pm_susp_reset_computermachinepasswo.title: Suspicious Computer Machine Password by PowerShell
posh_pm_susp_reset_computermachinepasswo.status:
The Reset-ComputerMachinePassword cmdlet changes the computer account password that the computers use to authenticate to the domain controllers in the domain.
You can use it to reset the password of the local computer.

posh_pm_susp_smb_share_reco.yml.status:
Adversaries may look for folders and drives shared on remote systems as a means of identifying sources of information to gather as a precursor for Collection and
to identify potential systems of interest for Lateral Movement.
Networks often contain shared network drives and folders that enable users to access file directories on various systems across a network.

posh_ps_access_to_browser_login_data.yml.title: Access to Browser Login Data
posh_ps_access_to_browser_login_data.yml.status:
Adversaries may acquire credentials from web browsers by reading files specific to the target browser.
Web browsers commonly save credentials such as website usernames and passwords so that they do not need to be entered manually in the future.
Web browsers typically store the credentials in an encrypted format within a credential store.

posh_ps_cor_profiler.yml.title: Registry-Free Process Scope COR_PROFILER
posh_ps_cor_profiler.yml.status:
Adversaries may leverage the COR_PROFILER environment variable to hijack the execution flow of programs that load the .NET CLR.
The COR_PROFILER is a .NET Framework feature which allows developers to specify an unmanaged (or external of .NET) profiling DLL to be loaded into each .NET process that loads the Common Language Runtime (CLR).
These profiliers are designed to monitor, troubleshoot, and debug managed code executed by the .NET CLR.
(Citation: Microsoft Profiling Mar 2017)
(Citation: Microsoft COR_PROFILER Feb 2013)
posh_ps_cor_profiler.yml.description:
Adversaries may leverage the COR_PROFILER environment variable to hijack the execution flow of programs that load the .NET CLR.
The COR_PROFILER is a .NET Framework feature which allows developers to specify an unmanaged (or external of .NET) profiling DLL to be loaded into each .NET process that loads the Common Language Runtime (CLR).
These profiliers are designed to monitor, troubleshoot, and debug managed code executed by the .NET CLR.
(Citation: Microsoft Profiling Mar 2017)
(Citation: Microsoft COR_PROFILER Feb 2013)
posh_ps_cor_profiler.yml.author: frack113

including whether or not the adversary fully infects the target and/or attempts specific actions.

Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the Registry entries used by services.

Windows stores local service configuration information in the Registry under HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services

posh_ps_susp_execute_batch_script.yml.title: Powershell Execute Batch Script
posh_ps_susp_execute_batch_script.yml.status:
Adversaries may abuse the Windows command shell for execution.
The Windows command shell ([cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106)) is the primary command prompt on Windows systems.
The Windows command prompt can be used to control almost any aspect of a system, with various permission levels required for different subsets of commands.
Batch files (ex: .bat or .cmd) also provide the shell with a list of sequential commands to run, as well as normal scripting operations such as conditionals and loops.
Common uses of batch files include long or repetitive tasks, or the need to run the same set of commands on multiple system
posh_ps_susp_execute_batch_script.yml.description:
Adversaries may abuse the Windows command shell for execution.
The Windows command shell ([cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106)) is the primary command prompt on Windows systems.
The Windows command prompt can be used to control almost any aspect of a system, with various permission levels required for different subsets of commands.
Batch files (ex: .bat or .cmd) also provide the shell with a list of sequential commands to run, as well as normal scripting operations such as conditionals and loops.
Common uses of batch files include long or repetitive tasks, or the need to run the same set of commands on multiple system
posh_ps_susp_execute_batch_script.yml.author: frack113

logsource.definition: Requirements: Script Block Logging must be enabled

posh_ps_susp_extracting.yml.status:

These can be files created by users to store their own credentials, shared credential stores for a group of individuals,
configuration files containing passwords for a system or service, or source code/binary files containing embedded passwords.

posh_ps_timestomp.yml.title: Powershell Timestomp
posh_ps_timestomp.yml.status:
Adversaries may modify file time attributes to hide new or changes to existing files.
Timestomping is a technique that modifies the timestamps of a file (the modify, access, create, and change times), often to mimic files that are in the same folder.

posh_ps_winlogon_helper_dll.yml.title: Winlogon Helper DLL
posh_ps_winlogon_helper_dll.yml.status:
Winlogon.exe is a Windows component responsible for actions at logon/logoff as well as the secure attention sequence (SAS) triggered by Ctrl-Alt-Delete.
Registry entries in HKLM\Software[Wow6432Node]Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ and HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ are
used to manage additional helper programs and functionalities that support Winlogon. Malicious modifications to these Registry keys may cause Winlogon to
load and execute malicious DLLs and/or executables.
posh_ps_winlogon_helper_dll.yml.description:
Winlogon.exe is a Windows component responsible for actions at logon/logoff as well as the secure attention sequence (SAS) triggered by Ctrl-Alt-Delete.
Registry entries in HKLM\Software[Wow6432Node]Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ and HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ are
used to manage additional helper programs and functionalities that support Winlogon. Malicious modifications to these Registry keys may cause Winlogon to
load and execute malicious DLLs and/or executables.
posh_ps_winlogon_helper_dll.yml.author: Timur Zinniatullin, oscd.community

proc_creation_win_auditpol_nt_resource_k.title: Audit Policy Tampering Via NT Resource Kit Auditpol
proc_creation_win_auditpol_nt_resource_k.status:
Threat actors can use an older version of the auditpol binary available inside the NT resource kit to change audit policy configuration to impair detection capability.
This can be carried out by selectively disabling/removing certain audit policies as well as restoring a custom policy owned by the threat actor.
proc_creation_win_auditpol_nt_resource_k.description:
Threat actors can use an older version of the auditpol binary available inside the NT resource kit to change audit policy configuration to impair detection capability.
This can be carried out by selectively disabling/removing certain audit policies as well as restoring a custom policy owned by the threat actor.
proc_creation_win_auditpol_nt_resource_k.author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
falsepositives: The old auditpol utility isn't available by default on recent versions of Windows as it was replaced by a newer version. The FP rate should be very low except for tools that use a similar flag structure

This can be carried out by selectively disabling/removing certain audit policies as well as restoring a custom policy owned by the threat actor.
proc_creation_win_auditpol_susp_executio.description:
Threat actors can use auditpol binary to change audit policy configuration to impair detection capability.
This can be carried out by selectively disabling/removing certain audit policies as well as restoring a custom policy owned by the threat actor.
proc_creation_win_auditpol_susp_executio.author: Janantha Marasinghe (https://github.com/blueteam0ps)
falsepositives: Administrator or administrator scripts might leverage the flags mentioned in the detection section. Either way, it should always be monitored

proc_creation_win_bitsadmin_potential_pe.title: Monitoring For Persistence Via BITS
proc_creation_win_bitsadmin_potential_pe.status: BITS will allow you to schedule a command to execute after a successful download to notify you that the job is finished. When the job runs on the system the command specified in the BITS job will be executed. This can be abused by actors to create a backdoor within the system and for persistence. It will be chained in a BITS job to schedule the download of malware/additional binaries and execute the program after being downloaded
proc_creation_win_bitsadmin_potential_pe.description: BITS will allow you to schedule a command to execute after a successful download to notify you that the job is finished. When the job runs on the system the command specified in the BITS job will be executed. This can be abused by actors to create a backdoor within the system and for persistence. It will be chained in a BITS job to schedule the download of malware/additional binaries and execute the program after being downloaded
proc_creation_win_bitsadmin_potential_pe.author: Sreeman

proc_creation_win_certmgr_certificate_in.title: New Root Certificate Installed Via CertMgr.EXE
proc_creation_win_certmgr_certificate_in.status:
Detects execution of "certmgr" with the "add" flag in order to install a new certificate on the system.
Adversaries may install a root certificate on a compromised system to avoid warnings when connecting to adversary controlled web servers.
proc_creation_win_certmgr_certificate_in.description:
Detects execution of "certmgr" with the "add" flag in order to install a new certificate on the system.
Adversaries may install a root certificate on a compromised system to avoid warnings when connecting to adversary controlled web servers.
proc_creation_win_certmgr_certificate_in.author: oscd.community, @redcanary, Zach Stanford @svch0st
falsepositives: Help Desk or IT may need to manually add a corporate Root CA on occasion. Need to test if GPO push doesn't trigger FP

proc_creation_win_cipher_overwrite_delet.title: Deleted Data Overwritten Via Cipher.EXE
proc_creation_win_cipher_overwrite_delet.status:
Detects usage of the "cipher" built-in utility in order to overwrite deleted data from disk.
Adversaries may destroy data and files on specific systems or in large numbers on a network to interrupt availability to systems, services, and network resources.
Data destruction is likely to render stored data irrecoverable by forensic techniques through overwriting files or data on local and remote drives
proc_creation_win_cipher_overwrite_delet.description:
Detects usage of the "cipher" built-in utility in order to overwrite deleted data from disk.
Adversaries may destroy data and files on specific systems or in large numbers on a network to interrupt availability to systems, services, and network resources.
Data destruction is likely to render stored data irrecoverable by forensic techniques through overwriting files or data on local and remote drives
proc_creation_win_cipher_overwrite_delet.author: frack113

proc_creation_win_cmd_assoc_execution.ym.title: Change Default File Association Via Assoc
proc_creation_win_cmd_assoc_execution.ym.status:
Detects file association changes using the builtin "assoc" command.
When a file is opened, the default program used to open the file (also called the file association or handler) is checked. File association selections are stored in the Windows Registry and can be edited by users, administrators, or programs that have Registry access or by administrators using the built-in assoc utility. Applications can modify the file association for a given file extension to call an arbitrary program when a file with the given extension is opened.
proc_creation_win_cmd_assoc_execution.ym.description:
Detects file association changes using the builtin "assoc" command.

Applications can modify the file association for a given file extension to call an arbitrary program when a file with the given extension is opened.
proc_creation_win_cmd_assoc_execution.ym.author: Timur Zinniatullin, oscd.community

proc_creation_win_cmd_assoc_tamper_exe_f.title: Change Default File Association To Executable Via Assoc
proc_creation_win_cmd_assoc_tamper_exe_f.status:
Detects when a program changes the default file association of any extension to an executable.
When a file is opened, the default program used to open the file (also called the file association or handler) is checked. File association selections are stored in the Windows Registry and can be edited by users, administrators, or programs that have Registry access or by administrators using the built-in assoc utility. Applications can modify the file association for a given file extension to call an arbitrary program when a file with the given extension is opened.

proc_creation_win_cmd_del_execution.yml.title: File Deletion Via Del
proc_creation_win_cmd_del_execution.yml.status:
Detects execution of the builtin "del"/"erase" commands in order to delete files.
Adversaries may delete files left behind by the actions of their intrusion activity.
Malware, tools, or other non-native files dropped or created on a system by an adversary may leave traces to indicate to what was done within a network and how.
Removal of these files can occur during an intrusion, or as part of a post-intrusion process to minimize the adversary's footprint.
proc_creation_win_cmd_del_execution.yml.description:
Detects execution of the builtin "del"/"erase" commands in order to delete files.
Adversaries may delete files left behind by the actions of their intrusion activity.
Malware, tools, or other non-native files dropped or created on a system by an adversary may leave traces to indicate to what was done within a network and how.
Removal of these files can occur during an intrusion, or as part of a post-intrusion process to minimize the adversary's footprint.
proc_creation_win_cmd_del_execution.yml.author: frack113
falsepositives: False positives levels will differ Depending on the environment. You can use a combination of ParentImage and other keywords from the CommandLine field to filter legitimate activity

proc_creation_win_cmd_del_greedy_deletio.title: Greedy File Deletion Using Del
proc_creation_win_cmd_del_greedy_deletio.status: Detects execution of the "del" builtin command to remove files using greedy/wildcard expression. This is often used by malware to delete content of folders that perhaps contains the initial malware infection or to delete evidence.

proc_creation_win_cmd_sticky_keys_replac.title: Persistence Via Sticky Key Backdoor
proc_creation_win_cmd_sticky_keys_replac.status:
By replacing the sticky keys executable with the local admins CMD executable, an attacker is able to access a privileged windows console session without authenticating to the system.
When the sticky keys are "activated" the privilleged shell is launched.

proc_creation_win_csi_execution.yml.title: Suspicious Csi.exe Usage
proc_creation_win_csi_execution.yml.status: Csi.exe is a signed binary from Microsoft that comes with Visual Studio and provides C# interactive capabilities. It can be used to run C# code from a file passed as a parameter in command line. Early version of this utility provided with Microsoft “Roslyn” Community Technology Preview was named 'rcsi.exe'
proc_creation_win_csi_execution.yml.description: Csi.exe is a signed binary from Microsoft that comes with Visual Studio and provides C# interactive capabilities. proc_creation_win_deviceenroller_dll_sid.title: Potential DLL Sideloading Via DeviceEnroller.EXE
proc_creation_win_deviceenroller_dll_sid.status:
Detects the use of the PhoneDeepLink parameter to potentially sideload a DLL file that does not exist. This non-existent DLL file is named "ShellChromeAPI.dll".
Adversaries can drop their own renamed DLL and execute it via DeviceEnroller.exe using this parameter
proc_creation_win_deviceenroller_dll_sid.description:
Detects the use of the PhoneDeepLink parameter to potentially sideload a DLL file that does not exist. This non-existent DLL file is named "ShellChromeAPI.dll".
Adversaries can drop their own renamed DLL and execute it via DeviceEnroller.exe using this parameter
proc_creation_win_deviceenroller_dll_sid.author: @gott_cyber

Detects execution of "Diskshadow.exe" in script mode to execute an script with a potentially uncommon extension.
Initial baselining of the allowed extension list is required.

which is similar to cmd.exe /c, only it breaks the process tree and makes its parent a new instance of explorer spawning from "svchost"

proc_creation_win_fsutil_symlinkevaluati.title: Fsutil Behavior Set SymlinkEvaluation
proc_creation_win_fsutil_symlinkevaluati.status:
A symbolic link is a type of file that contains a reference to another file.
This is probably done to make sure that the ransomware is able to follow shortcuts on the machine in order to find the original file to encrypt

proc_creation_win_fsutil_usage.yml.title: Fsutil Suspicious Invocation
proc_creation_win_fsutil_usage.yml.status:
Detects suspicious parameters of fsutil (deleting USN journal, configuring it with small size, etc).
Might be used by ransomwares during the attack (seen by NotPetya and others).

proc_creation_win_homoglyph_cyrillic_loo.title: Potential Homoglyph Attack Using Lookalike Characters
proc_creation_win_homoglyph_cyrillic_loo.status:
Detects the presence of unicode characters which are homoglyphs, or identical in appearance, to ASCII letter characters.
This is used as an obfuscation and masquerading techniques. Only "perfect" homoglyphs are included; these are characters that
are indistinguishable from ASCII characters and thus may make excellent candidates for homoglyph attack characters.
proc_creation_win_homoglyph_cyrillic_loo.description:
Detects the presence of unicode characters which are homoglyphs, or identical in appearance, to ASCII letter characters.
This is used as an obfuscation and masquerading techniques. Only "perfect" homoglyphs are included; these are characters that
are indistinguishable from ASCII characters and thus may make excellent candidates for homoglyph attack characters.
proc_creation_win_homoglyph_cyrillic_loo.author: Micah Babinski, @micahbabinski
falsepositives: Commandlines with legitimate Cyrillic text; will likely require tuning (or not be usable) in countries where these alphabets are in use.

proc_creation_win_hxtsr_masquerading.yml.title: Fake Instance Of Hxtsr.exe
proc_creation_win_hxtsr_masquerading.yml.status:
HxTsr.exe is a Microsoft compressed executable file called Microsoft Outlook Communications.
HxTsr.exe is part of Outlook apps, because it resides in a hidden "WindowsApps" subfolder of "C:\Program Files".
Its path includes a version number, e.g., "C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\microsoft.windowscommunicationsapps_17.7466.41167.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe\HxTsr.exe".
Any instances of hxtsr.exe not in this folder may be malware camouflaging itself as HxTsr.exe
proc_creation_win_hxtsr_masquerading.yml.description:
HxTsr.exe is a Microsoft compressed executable file called Microsoft Outlook Communications.
HxTsr.exe is part of Outlook apps, because it resides in a hidden "WindowsApps" subfolder of "C:\Program Files".
Its path includes a version number, e.g., "C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\microsoft.windowscommunicationsapps_17.7466.41167.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe\HxTsr.exe".
Any instances of hxtsr.exe not in this folder may be malware camouflaging itself as HxTsr.exe

proc_creation_win_lolbin_appvlp.yml.title: Using AppVLP To Circumvent ASR File Path Rule
proc_creation_win_lolbin_appvlp.yml.status:
Application Virtualization Utility is included with Microsoft Office. We are able to abuse "AppVLP" to execute shell commands.
Normally, this binary is used for Application Virtualization, but we can use it as an abuse binary to circumvent the ASR file path rule folder
or to mark a file as a system file.
proc_creation_win_lolbin_appvlp.yml.description:
Application Virtualization Utility is included with Microsoft Office. We are able to abuse "AppVLP" to execute shell commands.
Normally, this binary is used for Application Virtualization, but we can use it as an abuse binary to circumvent the ASR file path rule folder
or to mark a file as a system file.
proc_creation_win_lolbin_appvlp.yml.author: Sreeman

falsepositives: Other VB scripts that leverage the same starting command line flags

proc_creation_win_mofcomp_execution.yml.title: Potential Suspicious Mofcomp Execution
proc_creation_win_mofcomp_execution.yml.status:
Detects execution of the "mofcomp" utility as a child of a suspicious shell or script running utility or by having a supsicious path in the commandline.
The "mofcomp" utility parses a file containing MOF statements and adds the classes and class instances defined in the file to the WMI repository.
Attackers abuse this utility to install malicious MOF scripts
proc_creation_win_mofcomp_execution.yml.description:
Detects execution of the "mofcomp" utility as a child of a suspicious shell or script running utility or by having a supsicious path in the commandline.
The "mofcomp" utility parses a file containing MOF statements and adds the classes and class instances defined in the file to the WMI repository.
Attackers abuse this utility to install malicious MOF scripts
proc_creation_win_mofcomp_execution.yml.author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

proc_creation_win_mssql_sqlps_susp_execu.title: Detection of PowerShell Execution via Sqlps.exe
proc_creation_win_mssql_sqlps_susp_execu.status:
This rule detects execution of a PowerShell code through the sqlps.exe utility, which is included in the standard set of utilities supplied with the MSSQL Server.
Script blocks are not logged in this case, so this utility helps to bypass protection mechanisms based on the analysis of these logs.
proc_creation_win_mssql_sqlps_susp_execu.description:
This rule detects execution of a PowerShell code through the sqlps.exe utility, which is included in the standard set of utilities supplied with the MSSQL Server.
Script blocks are not logged in this case, so this utility helps to bypass protection mechanisms based on the analysis of these logs.
proc_creation_win_mssql_sqlps_susp_execu.author: Agro (@agro_sev) oscd.community
falsepositives: Direct PS command execution through SQLPS.exe is uncommon, childprocess sqlps.exe spawned by sqlagent.exe is a legitimate action.

proc_creation_win_mssql_sqltoolsps_susp_.title: SQL Client Tools PowerShell Session Detection
proc_creation_win_mssql_sqltoolsps_susp_.status:
This rule detects execution of a PowerShell code through the sqltoolsps.exe utility, which is included in the standard set of utilities supplied with the Microsoft SQL Server Management studio.
Script blocks are not logged in this case, so this utility helps to bypass protection mechanisms based on the analysis of these logs.
proc_creation_win_mssql_sqltoolsps_susp_.description:
This rule detects execution of a PowerShell code through the sqltoolsps.exe utility, which is included in the standard set of utilities supplied with the Microsoft SQL Server Management studio.
Script blocks are not logged in this case, so this utility helps to bypass protection mechanisms based on the analysis of these logs.
proc_creation_win_mssql_sqltoolsps_susp_.author: Agro (@agro_sev) oscd.communitly
falsepositives: Direct PS command execution through SQLToolsPS.exe is uncommon, childprocess sqltoolsps.exe spawned by smss.exe is a legitimate action.

proc_creation_win_mstsc_remote_connectio.title: New Remote Desktop Connection Initiated Via Mstsc.EXE
proc_creation_win_mstsc_remote_connectio.status:
Detects the usage of "mstsc.exe" with the "/v" flag to initiate a connection to a remote server.
Adversaries may use valid accounts to log into a computer using the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.

Adversaries may use valid accounts to log into a computer using the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.
proc_creation_win_mstsc_remote_connectio.author: frack113

proc_creation_win_network_sniffing.yml.title: Potential Network Sniffing Activity Using Network Tools
proc_creation_win_network_sniffing.yml.status:
Detects potential network sniffing via use of network tools such as "tshark", "windump".
Network sniffing refers to using the network interface on a system to monitor or capture information sent over a wired or wireless connection.
An adversary may place a network interface into promiscuous mode to passively access data in transit over the network, or use span ports to capture a larger amount of data.
proc_creation_win_network_sniffing.yml.description:
Detects potential network sniffing via use of network tools such as "tshark", "windump".
Network sniffing refers to using the network interface on a system to monitor or capture information sent over a wired or wireless connection.
An adversary may place a network interface into promiscuous mode to passively access data in transit over the network, or use span ports to capture a larger amount of data.
proc_creation_win_network_sniffing.yml.author: Timur Zinniatullin, oscd.community, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
falsepositives: Legitimate administration activity to troubleshoot network issues

proc_creation_win_odbcconf_driver_instal.title: Driver/DLL Installation Via Odbcconf.EXE
proc_creation_win_odbcconf_driver_instal.status: Detects execution of "odbcconf" with "INSTALLDRIVER" which installs a new ODBC driver. Attackers abuse this to install and run malicious DLLs.

falsepositives: Legitimate driver DLLs being registered via "odbcconf" will generate false positives. Investigate the path of the DLL and its contents to determine if the action is authorized.

detection.condition: all of selection_* and not 1 of filter_main_*

falsepositives: The rule is looking for any usage of response file, which might generate false positive when this function is used legitimately. Investigate the contents of the ".rsp" file to determine if it is malicious and apply additional filters if necessary.

proc_creation_win_odbcconf_uncommon_chil.title: Uncommon Child Process Spawned By Odbcconf.EXE
proc_creation_win_odbcconf_uncommon_chil.status: Detects an uncommon child process of "odbcconf.exe" binary which normally shouldn't have any child processes.
proc_creation_win_odbcconf_uncommon_chil.description: Detects an uncommon child process of "odbcconf.exe" binary which normally shouldn't have any child processes.
proc_creation_win_odbcconf_uncommon_chil.author: Harjot Singh @cyb3rjy0t
falsepositives: In rare occurrences where "odbcconf" crashes. It might spawn a "werfault" process

Other child processes will depend on the DLL being registered by actions like "regsvr". In case where the DLLs have external calls (which should be rare). Other child processes might spawn and additional filters need to be applied.

proc_creation_win_office_exec_from_trust.status: Detects the execution of an Office application that points to a document that is located in a trusted location. Attackers often used this to avoid macro security and execute their malicious code.

proc_creation_win_office_svchost_parent..title: Suspicious New Instance Of An Office COM Object
proc_creation_win_office_svchost_parent..status:
Detects an svchost process spawning an instance of an office application. This happens when the initial word application creates an instance of one of the Office COM objects such as 'Word.Application', 'Excel.Application', etc.
This can be used by malicious actors to create malicious Office documents with macros on the fly. (See vba2clr project in the references)
proc_creation_win_office_svchost_parent..description:
Detects an svchost process spawning an instance of an office application. This happens when the initial word application creates an instance of one of the Office COM objects such as 'Word.Application', 'Excel.Application', etc.
This can be used by malicious actors to create malicious Office documents with macros on the fly. (See vba2clr project in the references)
proc_creation_win_office_svchost_parent..author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
falsepositives: Legitimate usage of office automation via scripting

proc_creation_win_office_winword_dll_loa.title: Potential Arbitrary DLL Load Using Winword

proc_creation_win_offlinescannershell_mp.title: Potential Mpclient.DLL Sideloading Via OfflineScannerShell.EXE Execution
proc_creation_win_offlinescannershell_mp.status:
Detects execution of Windows Defender "OfflineScannerShell.exe" from its non standard directory.
The "OfflineScannerShell.exe" binary is vulnerable to DLL side loading and will load any DLL named "mpclient.dll" from the current working directory.
proc_creation_win_offlinescannershell_mp.description:
Detects execution of Windows Defender "OfflineScannerShell.exe" from its non standard directory.
The "OfflineScannerShell.exe" binary is vulnerable to DLL side loading and will load any DLL named "mpclient.dll" from the current working directory.
proc_creation_win_offlinescannershell_mp.author: frack113

proc_creation_win_powershell_enable_susp.title: Potential Suspicious Windows Feature Enabled - ProcCreation
proc_creation_win_powershell_enable_susp.status:
Detects usage of the built-in PowerShell cmdlet "Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature" used as a Deployment Image Servicing and Management tool.
Similar to DISM.exe, this cmdlet is used to enumerate, install, uninstall, configure, and update features and packages in Windows images
proc_creation_win_powershell_enable_susp.description:
Detects usage of the built-in PowerShell cmdlet "Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature" used as a Deployment Image Servicing and Management tool.
Similar to DISM.exe, this cmdlet is used to enumerate, install, uninstall, configure, and update features and packages in Windows images
proc_creation_win_powershell_enable_susp.author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
falsepositives: Legitimate usage of the features listed in the rule.

proc_creation_win_powershell_reverse_she.description: Detects usage of the "TcpClient" class. Which can be abused to establish remote connections and reverse-shells. As seen used by the Nishang "Invoke-PowerShellTcpOneLine" reverse shell and other.

proc_creation_win_reg_enumeration_for_cr.title: Enumeration for Credentials in Registry
proc_creation_win_reg_enumeration_for_cr.status:
Adversaries may search the Registry on compromised systems for insecurely stored credentials.
The Windows Registry stores configuration information that can be used by the system or other programs.
Adversaries may query the Registry looking for credentials and passwords that have been stored for use by other programs or services
proc_creation_win_reg_enumeration_for_cr.description:
Adversaries may search the Registry on compromised systems for insecurely stored credentials.
The Windows Registry stores configuration information that can be used by the system or other programs.
Adversaries may query the Registry looking for credentials and passwords that have been stored for use by other programs or services

proc_creation_win_reg_lsa_disable_restri.title: Disabled RestrictedAdminMode For RDS - ProcCreation
proc_creation_win_reg_lsa_disable_restri.status:
Detect activation of DisableRestrictedAdmin to desable RestrictedAdmin mode.
RestrictedAdmin mode prevents the transmission of reusable credentials to the remote system to which you connect using Remote Desktop.
This prevents your credentials from being harvested during the initial connection process if the remote server has been compromise
proc_creation_win_reg_lsa_disable_restri.description:
Detect activation of DisableRestrictedAdmin to desable RestrictedAdmin mode.
RestrictedAdmin mode prevents the transmission of reusable credentials to the remote system to which you connect using Remote Desktop.
This prevents your credentials from being harvested during the initial connection process if the remote server has been compromise

proc_creation_win_reg_screensaver.yml.title: Suspicious ScreenSave Change by Reg.exe
proc_creation_win_reg_screensaver.yml.status:
Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by user inactivity.
Screensavers are programs that execute after a configurable time of user inactivity and consist of Portable Executable (PE) files with a .scr file extension
proc_creation_win_reg_screensaver.yml.description:
Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by user inactivity.
Screensavers are programs that execute after a configurable time of user inactivity and consist of Portable Executable (PE) files with a .scr file extension
proc_creation_win_reg_screensaver.yml.author: frack113

proc_creation_win_reg_service_imagepath_.title: Changing Existing Service ImagePath Value Via Reg.EXE
proc_creation_win_reg_service_imagepath_.status:
Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the Registry entries used by services.
Adversaries may use flaws in the permissions for registry to redirect from the originally specified executable to one that they control, in order to launch their own code at Service start.
Windows stores local service configuration information in the Registry under HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services
proc_creation_win_reg_service_imagepath_.description:
Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the Registry entries used by services.
Adversaries may use flaws in the permissions for registry to redirect from the originally specified executable to one that they control, in order to launch their own code at Service start.
Windows stores local service configuration information in the Registry under HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services
proc_creation_win_reg_service_imagepath_.author: frack113

This allows downloaded files from the Internet to be granted the same level of trust as files stored locally.

proc_creation_win_remote_access_software.title: Use of UltraViewer Remote Access Software
proc_creation_win_remote_access_software.status:
An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks.
These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment.
Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)

proc_creation_win_renamed_autoit.yml.title: Renamed AutoIt Execution
proc_creation_win_renamed_autoit.yml.status:
Detects the execution of a renamed AutoIt2.exe or AutoIt3.exe.
AutoIt is a scripting language and automation tool for Windows systems. While primarily used for legitimate automation tasks, it can be misused in cyber attacks.
Attackers can leverage AutoIt to create and distribute malware, including keyloggers, spyware, and botnets. A renamed AutoIt executable is particularly suspicious.
proc_creation_win_renamed_autoit.yml.description:

proc_creation_win_renamed_autoit.yml.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

proc_creation_win_rundll32_setupapi_inst.title: Suspicious Rundll32 Setupapi.dll Activity
proc_creation_win_rundll32_setupapi_inst.status: setupapi.dll library provide InstallHinfSection function for processing INF files. INF file may contain instructions allowing to create values in the registry, modify files and install drivers. This technique could be used to obtain persistence via modifying one of Run or RunOnce registry keys, run process or use other DLLs chain calls (see references) InstallHinfSection function in setupapi.dll calls runonce.exe executable regardless of actual content of INF file.
proc_creation_win_rundll32_setupapi_inst.description: setupapi.dll library provide InstallHinfSection function for processing INF files. INF file may contain instructions allowing to create values in the registry, modify files and install drivers. This technique could be used to obtain persistence via modifying one of Run or RunOnce registry keys, run process or use other DLLs chain calls (see references) InstallHinfSection function in setupapi.dll calls runonce.exe executable regardless of actual content of INF file.
proc_creation_win_rundll32_setupapi_inst.author: Konstantin Grishchenko, oscd.community
falsepositives: Scripts and administrative tools that use INF files for driver installation with setupapi.dll

proc_creation_win_rundll32_webdav_client.title: WebDav Client Execution Via Rundll32.EXE
proc_creation_win_rundll32_webdav_client.status:
Detects "svchost.exe" spawning "rundll32.exe" with command arguments like "C:\windows\system32\davclnt.dll,DavSetCookie".
This could be an indicator of exfiltration or use of WebDav to launch code (hosted on a WebDav server).
proc_creation_win_rundll32_webdav_client.description:
Detects "svchost.exe" spawning "rundll32.exe" with command arguments like "C:\windows\system32\davclnt.dll,DavSetCookie".
This could be an indicator of exfiltration or use of WebDav to launch code (hosted on a WebDav server).
proc_creation_win_rundll32_webdav_client.author: Roberto Rodriguez (Cyb3rWard0g), OTR (Open Threat Research)

This could be an indicator of exfiltration or use of WebDav to launch code (hosted on WebDav Server) or potentially a sign of exploitation of CVE-2023-23397
proc_creation_win_rundll32_webdav_client.description: Detects "svchost.exe" spawning "rundll32.exe" with command arguments like C:\windows\system32\davclnt.dll,DavSetCookie. proc_creation_win_schtasks_change.yml.title: Suspicious Modification Of Scheduled Tasks
proc_creation_win_schtasks_change.yml.status:
Detects when an attacker tries to modify an already existing scheduled tasks to run from a suspicious location
Attackers can create a simple looking task in order to avoid detection on creation as it's often the most focused on
Instead they modify the task after creation to include their malicious payload
proc_creation_win_schtasks_change.yml.description:
Detects when an attacker tries to modify an already existing scheduled tasks to run from a suspicious location
Attackers can create a simple looking task in order to avoid detection on creation as it's often the most focused on
Instead they modify the task after creation to include their malicious payload

proc_creation_win_susp_bad_opsec_sacrifi.title: Bad Opsec Defaults Sacrificial Processes With Improper Arguments
proc_creation_win_susp_bad_opsec_sacrifi.status:
Detects attackers using tooling with bad opsec defaults.
E.g. spawning a sacrificial process to inject a capability into the process without taking into account how the process is normally run.
One trivial example of this is using rundll32.exe without arguments as a sacrificial process (default in CS, now highlighted by c2lint), running WerFault without arguments (Kraken - credit am0nsec), and other examples.
proc_creation_win_susp_bad_opsec_sacrifi.description:
Detects attackers using tooling with bad opsec defaults.
E.g. spawning a sacrificial process to inject a capability into the process without taking into account how the process is normally run.
One trivial example of this is using rundll32.exe without arguments as a sacrificial process (default in CS, now highlighted by c2lint), running WerFault without arguments (Kraken - credit am0nsec), and other examples.
proc_creation_win_susp_bad_opsec_sacrifi.author: Oleg Kolesnikov @securonix invrep_de, oscd.community, Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Christian Burkard (Nextron Systems)

proc_creation_win_susp_copy_browser_data.title: Potential Browser Data Stealing
proc_creation_win_susp_copy_browser_data.status:
Adversaries may acquire credentials from web browsers by reading files specific to the target browser.
Web browsers commonly save credentials such as website usernames and passwords so that they do not need to be entered manually in the future.
Web browsers typically store the credentials in an encrypted format within a credential store.
proc_creation_win_susp_copy_browser_data.description:
Adversaries may acquire credentials from web browsers by reading files specific to the target browser.
Web browsers commonly save credentials such as website usernames and passwords so that they do not need to be entered manually in the future.
Web browsers typically store the credentials in an encrypted format within a credential store.

proc_creation_win_susp_copy_system_dir.y.title: Suspicious Copy From or To System Directory
proc_creation_win_susp_copy_system_dir.y.status:
Detects a suspicious copy operation that tries to copy a program from system (System32, SysWOW64, WinSxS) directories to another on disk.
Often used to move LOLBINs such as 'certutil' or 'desktopimgdownldr' to a different location with a different name in order to bypass detections based on locations.
proc_creation_win_susp_copy_system_dir.y.description:
Detects a suspicious copy operation that tries to copy a program from system (System32, SysWOW64, WinSxS) directories to another on disk.
Often used to move LOLBINs such as 'certutil' or 'desktopimgdownldr' to a different location with a different name in order to bypass detections based on locations.
proc_creation_win_susp_copy_system_dir.y.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, Tim Shelton (HAWK.IO), Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
falsepositives: Depend on scripts and administrative tools used in the monitored environment (For example an admin scripts like https://www.itexperience.net/sccm-batch-files-and-32-bits-processes-on-64-bits-os/)
When cmd.exe and xcopy.exe are called directly
When the command contains the keywords but not in the correct order

proc_creation_win_susp_right_to_left_ove.title: Potential Defense Evasion Via Right-to-Left Override
proc_creation_win_susp_right_to_left_ove.status:
Detects the presence of the "u202+E" character, which causes a terminal, browser, or operating system to render text in a right-to-left sequence.
This is used as an obfuscation and masquerading techniques.
proc_creation_win_susp_right_to_left_ove.description:

This is used as an obfuscation and masquerading techniques.
proc_creation_win_susp_right_to_left_ove.author: Micah Babinski, @micahbabinski
falsepositives: Commandlines that contains scriptures such as arabic or hebrew might make use of this character

CommandLine|contains: Avast Business Console Client Antivirus Service

proc_creation_win_susp_task_folder_evasi.title: Tasks Folder Evasion
proc_creation_win_susp_task_folder_evasi.status:
The Tasks folder in system32 and syswow64 are globally writable paths.
Adversaries can take advantage of this and load or influence any script hosts or ANY .NET Application 
in Tasks to load and execute a custom assembly into cscript, wscript, regsvr32, mshta, eventvwr
proc_creation_win_susp_task_folder_evasi.description:
The Tasks folder in system32 and syswow64 are globally writable paths.
Adversaries can take advantage of this and load or influence any script hosts or ANY .NET Application 
in Tasks to load and execute a custom assembly into cscript, wscript, regsvr32, mshta, eventvwr
proc_creation_win_susp_task_folder_evasi.author: Sreeman

proc_creation_win_susp_use_of_te_bin.yml.title: Malicious Windows Script Components File Execution by TAEF Detection
proc_creation_win_susp_use_of_te_bin.yml.status:
Windows Test Authoring and Execution Framework (TAEF) framework allows you to run automation by executing tests files written on different languages (C, C#, Microsoft COM Scripting interfaces
Adversaries may execute malicious code (such as WSC file with VBScript, dll and so on) directly by running te.exe
proc_creation_win_susp_use_of_te_bin.yml.description:
Windows Test Authoring and Execution Framework (TAEF) framework allows you to run automation by executing tests files written on different languages (C, C#, Microsoft COM Scripting interfaces
Adversaries may execute malicious code (such as WSC file with VBScript, dll and so on) directly by running te.exe
proc_creation_win_susp_use_of_te_bin.yml.author: Agro (@agro_sev) oscd.community
falsepositives: It's not an uncommon to use te.exe directly to execute legal TAEF tests

proc_creation_win_susp_use_of_vsjitdebug.title: Malicious PE Execution by Microsoft Visual Studio Debugger
proc_creation_win_susp_use_of_vsjitdebug.status:
There is an option for a MS VS Just-In-Time Debugger "vsjitdebugger.exe" to launch specified executable and attach a debugger.
This option may be used adversaries to execute malicious code by signed verified binary.
The debugger is installed alongside with Microsoft Visual Studio package.
proc_creation_win_susp_use_of_vsjitdebug.description:
There is an option for a MS VS Just-In-Time Debugger "vsjitdebugger.exe" to launch specified executable and attach a debugger.
This option may be used adversaries to execute malicious code by signed verified binary.
The debugger is installed alongside with Microsoft Visual Studio package.
proc_creation_win_susp_use_of_vsjitdebug.author: Agro (@agro_sev), Ensar Şamil (@sblmsrsn), oscd.community
falsepositives: The process spawned by vsjitdebugger.exe is uncommon.

proc_creation_win_svchost_execution_with.status: It is extremely abnormal for svchost.exe to spawn without any CLI arguments and is normally observed when a malicious process spawns the process and injects code into the process memory space.

proc_creation_win_sysinternals_procdump_.title: Potential SysInternals ProcDump Evasion
proc_creation_win_sysinternals_procdump_.status: Detects uses of the SysInternals ProcDump utility in which ProcDump or its output get renamed, or a dump file is moved or copied to a different name
proc_creation_win_sysinternals_procdump_.description: Detects uses of the SysInternals ProcDump utility in which ProcDump or its output get renamed, or a dump file is moved or copied to a different name
proc_creation_win_sysinternals_procdump_.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

proc_creation_win_sysinternals_procdump_.title: Potential LSASS Process Dump Via Procdump
proc_creation_win_sysinternals_procdump_.status:
Detects suspicious uses of the SysInternals Procdump utility by using a special command line parameter in combination with the lsass.exe process.
This way we are also able to catch cases in which the attacker has renamed the procdump executable.
proc_creation_win_sysinternals_procdump_.description:
Detects suspicious uses of the SysInternals Procdump utility by using a special command line parameter in combination with the lsass.exe process.
This way we are also able to catch cases in which the attacker has renamed the procdump executable.
proc_creation_win_sysinternals_procdump_.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)
falsepositives: Unlikely, because no one should dump an lsass process memory
Another tool that uses command line flags similar to ProcDump

proc_creation_win_taskkill_sep.yml.title: Taskkill Symantec Endpoint Protection
proc_creation_win_taskkill_sep.yml.status:
Detects one of the possible scenarios for disabling Symantec Endpoint Protection.
Symantec Endpoint Protection antivirus software services incorrectly implement the protected service mechanism.
As a result, the NT AUTHORITY/SYSTEM user can execute the taskkill /im command several times ccSvcHst.exe /f, thereby killing the process belonging to the service, and thus shutting down the service.
proc_creation_win_taskkill_sep.yml.description:
Detects one of the possible scenarios for disabling Symantec Endpoint Protection.
Symantec Endpoint Protection antivirus software services incorrectly implement the protected service mechanism.
As a result, the NT AUTHORITY/SYSTEM user can execute the taskkill /im command several times ccSvcHst.exe /f, thereby killing the process belonging to the service, and thus shutting down the service.
proc_creation_win_taskkill_sep.yml.author: Ilya Krestinichev, Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

proc_creation_win_virtualbox_execution.y.title: Detect Virtualbox Driver Installation OR Starting Of VMs

proc_creation_win_virtualbox_vboxdrvinst.title: Suspicious VBoxDrvInst.exe Parameters
proc_creation_win_virtualbox_vboxdrvinst.status:
Detect VBoxDrvInst.exe run with parameters allowing processing INF file.
This allows to create values in the registry and install drivers.
For example one could use this technique to obtain persistence via modifying one of Run or RunOnce registry keys
proc_creation_win_virtualbox_vboxdrvinst.description:
Detect VBoxDrvInst.exe run with parameters allowing processing INF file.
This allows to create values in the registry and install drivers.
For example one could use this technique to obtain persistence via modifying one of Run or RunOnce registry keys
proc_creation_win_virtualbox_vboxdrvinst.author: Konstantin Grishchenko, oscd.community
falsepositives: Legitimate use of VBoxDrvInst.exe utility by VirtualBox Guest Additions installation process

internal network resources such as servers, tools/dashboards, or other related infrastructure.

proc_creation_win_winget_local_install_v.title: Install New Package Via Winget Local Manifest
proc_creation_win_winget_local_install_v.status:
Detects usage of winget to install applications via manifest file. Adversaries can abuse winget to download payloads remotely and execute them.
The manifest option enables you to install an application by passing in a YAML file directly to the client.
Winget can be used to download and install exe, msi or msix files later.
proc_creation_win_winget_local_install_v.description:
Detects usage of winget to install applications via manifest file. Adversaries can abuse winget to download payloads remotely and execute them.
The manifest option enables you to install an application by passing in a YAML file directly to the client.
Winget can be used to download and install exe, msi or msix files later.
proc_creation_win_winget_local_install_v.author: Sreeman, Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), frack113
falsepositives: Some false positives are expected in some environment that may use this functionality to install and test their custom applications

registry_add_persistence_disk_cleanup_ha.title: Potential Persistence Via Disk Cleanup Handler - Registry
registry_add_persistence_disk_cleanup_ha.status:
Detects when an attacker modifies values of the Disk Cleanup Handler in the registry to achieve persistence.
The disk cleanup manager is part of the operating system. It displays the dialog box […]
The user has the option of enabling or disabling individual handlers by selecting or clearing their check box in the disk cleanup manager's UI.
Although Windows comes with a number of disk cleanup handlers, they aren't designed to handle files produced by other applications.
Instead, the disk cleanup manager is designed to be flexible and extensible by enabling any developer to implement and register their own disk cleanup handler.
Any developer can extend the available disk cleanup services by implementing and registering a disk cleanup handler.
registry_add_persistence_disk_cleanup_ha.description:
Detects when an attacker modifies values of the Disk Cleanup Handler in the registry to achieve persistence.
The disk cleanup manager is part of the operating system. It displays the dialog box […]
The user has the option of enabling or disabling individual handlers by selecting or clearing their check box in the disk cleanup manager's UI.
Although Windows comes with a number of disk cleanup handlers, they aren't designed to handle files produced by other applications.
Instead, the disk cleanup manager is designed to be flexible and extensible by enabling any developer to implement and register their own disk cleanup handler.
Any developer can extend the available disk cleanup services by implementing and registering a disk cleanup handler.
registry_add_persistence_disk_cleanup_ha.author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)
falsepositives: Legitimate new entry added by windows

registry_set_amsi_com_hijack.yml.title: Potential AMSI COM Server Hijacking
registry_set_amsi_com_hijack.yml.status: Detects changes to the AMSI come server registry key in order disable AMSI scanning functionalities. When AMSI attempts to starts its COM component, it will query its registered CLSID and return a non-existent COM server. This causes a load failure and prevents any scanning methods from being accessed, ultimately rendering AMSI useless
registry_set_amsi_com_hijack.yml.description: Detects changes to the AMSI come server registry key in order disable AMSI scanning functionalities. When AMSI attempts to starts its COM component, it will query its registered CLSID and return a non-existent COM server. This causes a load failure and prevents any scanning methods from being accessed, ultimately rendering AMSI useless
registry_set_amsi_com_hijack.yml.author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

registry_set_change_rdp_port.yml.title: Changing RDP Port to Non Standard Number
registry_set_change_rdp_port.yml.status:
Remote desktop is a common feature in operating systems.
It allows a user to log into an interactive session with a system desktop graphical user interface on a remote system.
Microsoft refers to its implementation of the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) as Remote Desktop Services (RDS).
registry_set_change_rdp_port.yml.description:
Remote desktop is a common feature in operating systems.

Microsoft refers to its implementation of the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) as Remote Desktop Services (RDS).

registry_set_cobaltstrike_service_instal.title: CobaltStrike Service Installations in Registry
registry_set_cobaltstrike_service_instal.status:
Detects known malicious service installs that appear in cases in which a Cobalt Strike beacon elevates privileges or lateral movement.
We can also catch this by system log 7045 (https://github.com/SigmaHQ/sigma/blob/master/rules/windows/builtin/win_cobaltstrike_service_installs.yml)
In some SIEM you can catch those events also in HKLM\System\ControlSet001\Services or HKLM\System\ControlSet002\Services, however, this rule is based on a regular sysmon's events.
registry_set_cobaltstrike_service_instal.description:
Detects known malicious service installs that appear in cases in which a Cobalt Strike beacon elevates privileges or lateral movement.
We can also catch this by system log 7045 (https://github.com/SigmaHQ/sigma/blob/master/rules/windows/builtin/win_cobaltstrike_service_installs.yml)
In some SIEM you can catch those events also in HKLM\System\ControlSet001\Services or HKLM\System\ControlSet002\Services, however, this rule is based on a regular sysmon's events.
registry_set_cobaltstrike_service_instal.author: Wojciech Lesicki

registry_set_disk_cleanup_handler_autoru.title: Persistence Via Disk Cleanup Handler - Autorun
registry_set_disk_cleanup_handler_autoru.status:
Detects when an attacker modifies values of the Disk Cleanup Handler in the registry to achieve persistence via autorun.
The disk cleanup manager is part of the operating system.
It displays the dialog box […] The user has the option of enabling or disabling individual handlers by selecting or clearing their check box in the disk cleanup manager's UI.
Although Windows comes with a number of disk cleanup handlers, they aren't designed to handle files produced by other applications.
Instead, the disk cleanup manager is designed to be flexible and extensible by enabling any developer to implement and register their own disk cleanup handler.
Any developer can extend the available disk cleanup services by implementing and registering a disk cleanup handler.
registry_set_disk_cleanup_handler_autoru.description:
Detects when an attacker modifies values of the Disk Cleanup Handler in the registry to achieve persistence via autorun.
The disk cleanup manager is part of the operating system.
It displays the dialog box […] The user has the option of enabling or disabling individual handlers by selecting or clearing their check box in the disk cleanup manager's UI.
Although Windows comes with a number of disk cleanup handlers, they aren't designed to handle files produced by other applications.
Instead, the disk cleanup manager is designed to be flexible and extensible by enabling any developer to implement and register their own disk cleanup handler.
Any developer can extend the available disk cleanup services by implementing and registering a disk cleanup handler.
registry_set_disk_cleanup_handler_autoru.author: Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

registry_set_dns_over_https_enabled.yml.title: DNS-over-HTTPS Enabled by Registry
registry_set_dns_over_https_enabled.yml.status:
Detects when a user enables DNS-over-HTTPS.
This can be used to hide internet activity or be used to hide the process of exfiltrating data.
With this enabled organization will lose visibility into data such as query type, response and originating IP that are used to determine bad actors.

This prevents your credentials from being harvested during the initial connection process if the remote server has been compromise

registry_set_net_cli_ngenassemblyusagelo.title: NET NGenAssemblyUsageLog Registry Key Tamper
registry_set_net_cli_ngenassemblyusagelo.status:
Detects changes to the NGenAssemblyUsageLog registry key.
.NET Usage Log output location can be controlled by setting the NGenAssemblyUsageLog CLR configuration knob in the Registry or by configuring an environment variable (as described in the next section).
By simplify specifying an arbitrary value (e.g. fake output location or junk data) for the expected value, a Usage Log file for the .NET execution context will not be created.
registry_set_net_cli_ngenassemblyusagelo.description:
Detects changes to the NGenAssemblyUsageLog registry key.
.NET Usage Log output location can be controlled by setting the NGenAssemblyUsageLog CLR configuration knob in the Registry or by configuring an environment variable (as described in the next section).
By simplify specifying an arbitrary value (e.g. fake output location or junk data) for the expected value, a Usage Log file for the .NET execution context will not be created.
registry_set_net_cli_ngenassemblyusagelo.author: frack113

registry_set_persistence_app_paths.yml.title: Potential Persistence Via App Paths Default Property
registry_set_persistence_app_paths.yml.status:
Detects changes to the "Default" property for keys located in the \Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\App Paths\ registry. Which might be used as a method of persistence
The entries found under App Paths are used primarily for the following purposes.
First, to map an application's executable file name to that file's fully qualified path.
Second, to pre-pend information to the PATH environment variable on a per-application, per-process basis.
registry_set_persistence_app_paths.yml.description:
Detects changes to the "Default" property for keys located in the \Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\App Paths\ registry. Which might be used as a method of persistence
The entries found under App Paths are used primarily for the following purposes.
First, to map an application's executable file name to that file's fully qualified path.
Second, to pre-pend information to the PATH environment variable on a per-application, per-process basis.

The "Extensions" list contains filenames of DLLs being automatically loaded by lsass.exe. Each DLL has its InitializeLsaExtension() method called after loading.
registry_set_persistence_lsa_extension.y.description:

registry_set_susp_service_installed.yml.description:
Detects installation of NalDrv or PROCEXP152 services via registry-keys to non-system32 folders.
Both services are used in the tool Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs), which uses KDU (https://github.com/hfiref0x/KDU)
registry_set_susp_service_installed.yml.author: xknow (@xknow_infosec), xorxes (@xor_xes)
falsepositives: Other legimate tools using this service names and drivers. Note - clever attackers may easily bypass this detection by just renaming the services. Therefore just Medium-level and don't rely on it.

registry_set_telemetry_persistence.yml.title: Potential Registry Persistence Attempt Via Windows Telemetry
registry_set_telemetry_persistence.yml.status:
Detects potential persistence behavior using the windows telemetry registry key.
Windows telemetry makes use of the binary CompatTelRunner.exe to run a variety of commands and perform the actual telemetry collections.
This binary was created to be easily extensible, and to that end, it relies on the registry to instruct on which commands to run.
The problem is, it will run any arbitrary command without restriction of location or type.
registry_set_telemetry_persistence.yml.description:
Detects potential persistence behavior using the windows telemetry registry key.
Windows telemetry makes use of the binary CompatTelRunner.exe to run a variety of commands and perform the actual telemetry collections.
This binary was created to be easily extensible, and to that end, it relies on the registry to instruct on which commands to run.
The problem is, it will run any arbitrary command without restriction of location or type.
registry_set_telemetry_persistence.yml.author: Lednyov Alexey, oscd.community, Sreeman

logsource.definition: Requirements: Sysmon config that monitors \SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\AppCompatFlags\TelemetryController subkey of the HKLM hives

Such as allowing unauthorized users access to a system via the 'fAllowUnsolicited' or enabling RDP via 'fDenyTSConnections', etc.

registry_set_timeproviders_dllname.yml.title: Set TimeProviders DllName
registry_set_timeproviders_dllname.yml.status:
Detects processes setting a new DLL in DllName in under HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\W32Time\TimeProvider.
Adversaries may abuse time providers to execute DLLs when the system boots.
The Windows Time service (W32Time) enables time synchronization across and within domains.

registry_set_winlogon_allow_multiple_tss.title: Winlogon AllowMultipleTSSessions Enable
registry_set_winlogon_allow_multiple_tss.status:
Detects when the 'AllowMultipleTSSessions' value is enabled.
Which allows for multiple Remote Desktop connection sessions to be opened at once.
This is often used by attacker as a way to connect to an RDP session without disconnecting the other users

registry_set_winlogon_notify_key.yml.title: Winlogon Notify Key Logon Persistence
registry_set_winlogon_notify_key.yml.status:
Adversaries may abuse features of Winlogon to execute DLLs and/or executables when a user logs in.
Winlogon.exe is a Windows component responsible for actions at logon/logoff as well as the secure attention sequence (SAS) triggered by Ctrl-Alt-Delete.

registry_set_winlogon_notify_key.yml.author: frack113
